 TL:DR This game is great! However not because of the gameplay, which can be boring and tedious at times, but because of the great story and plot twists. Full Review This game has been talked about so much so I played this game with the highest of expectations. Shockingly I was still amazed by the twist! However to be completely honest, the story and atmosphere are the only two good things about this game. It has many issues, not many bugs but more gameplay issues. For example this game is mainly consisting of walking around a beautiful, atmospheric city and then doing tedious jobs that make you feel like the devs wasted a lot of cool oppurtunities with this game. I had to push myself through the story and the worst thing is that they dropped the twist on me when I was unsuspecting. It felt like I was just doing another boring mission and then all of a sudden  I capture ryan and kill him!? . However apart from the dated graphics (even for 2007!), the boring gameplay, terrible final boss and more, I still love this game for delivering such a strong story in a beautiful city. One thing I do love about ths game is the detail in the NPCs. This game is pretty good, and if you can force yourself to play it, you will be happy. 7.5/10 Pros:-Atmospheric city-Great story with a delicious twist!-Beginning of a great series-Epic Big daddys and Little sistersCons:-Boring and tedious gameplay at times (usually)-Dated graphics for 2007 (But they contribute to the atmosphere so it isn't that bad at all)-Bad boss fightOh, and if you would like some free game keys, join our group (I'm a mod): Accidently Reviewed  Was this review helpful or maybe even not helpful? 												Bioshock is first-person shooter action game developed by Irrational Games, 2K known as Boston / Australia in 2007.The game takes place in the 60s. The player, Jack survives a plane crash and reaches the underwater city Rapture found in decay. There he must fight against mutated humans and capture the substance called ADAM inside little girls called Little Systers that are defended by powerful Divers called Big Daddies. This substance will let the player acquire genetic improvements .Bioshock was really surprising because it created a whole new world with incredible narrative. history is noteworthy . Despite maps are not huge, they have superlative art and there are so many things to do that you never get bored . Combat is frenetic, there are turrets and machines to be hacked that provide ammunition and resources , there are also hidden resources and tonics to search that provide a remarkable range of combat.Instead of just owning guns, machine guns, etc. , we find tonics fire , electric rays, clouds of bees or many other forms of attack. This mixed mechanism was fairly new and fun at the time and it succeded on a very good game, Dishonored (2012), that took this concept and adapted it well .The game has elements of stealth, survival horror and role. It also has an important political component simulating an ultra-capitalist alternative world in a city where there are no ethical dilemmas and took to end the arts , science and engineering , which led to its decline .It is one of the top ranked games of all time . It has two sequels. The bioshock 2 showing an ultra communist character and Bioshock infinite that develops in an aerial city. In Bioshock infinite political, religious and scientific plot led to the end in a very elaborate story. It´s still a must have game in 2016.The game was released for Windows PC , PS3 and XBOX 360. The windows version required DirectX 9.0c API.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ESPAÑOL--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Bioshock es un videojuego de acción en primera persona desarrollado por Irrational Games, conocida como 2K Boston/Australia en 2007.El juego transcurre en los 60. El jugador, Jack, sobrevive a un accidente de avión y llega a la ciudad submarina Rapture que se encuentra en decadencia. Allí deberá luchar contra seres humanos mutados y capturar la sustancia ADAM de pequeñas niñas defendidas por poderosos Buzos llamados Big Daddies. Esta sustancia le perimitirá adquirir mejoras genéticas.Bioshock realmente sorprendió, ya que creó un mundo totalmente nuevo con una narrativa increible. la historia es digna de destacar. Si bien los mapas no son enormes, presentan un arte superlativo y hay tantas cosas que hacer que uno nunca se aburre. El combate es frenético, hay que hackear torretas y máquinas que brindan municiones y recursos, hay recursos ocultos para buscar y los tónicos brindan una variedad notoria al combate.En lugar de solo poseer pistolas, ametralladoras, etc, nos encontramos con tónicos de fuego, rayos eléctricos, nubes de abejas u muchas otras formas de ataque.  Este mecanismo mixto de combate fue bastante novedoso y diria que el muy buen juego Dishonored de 2012 tomó este concepto y lo adaptó muy bien.El juego posee elementos de sigilo, survival horror y rol. Además posee un importante componente político simulando una mundo alternativo en una ciudad ultracapitalista donde no hay dilemas éticos y se llevaron al extremo las artes, la ciencia y la ingeniería, lo que llevó a su decadencia. Es uno de los juegos mejor rankeados de todos los tiempos. Posee dos secuelas. El bioshock 2 que muestra un personaje ultra comunista y el Bioshock infinite que se desarrolla en una ciudad aérea y hay componentes políticos, religiosos y científicos  llevados al extremo en una historia muy elaborada. content:
Posted: August 13, 2013
												While most certainly BioShock has a unique style of an Underwater City and that enthralling 50's-60's Jazz and Blues culture, the game is not ideal...   It makes some attempts to include philosphy, allusions and metaphors in it's story. However they meet a dead end. None of them are adequately explained and thus the story lacks a certain emotional meaning, espcially when it comes to the "dilemma" of saving the little sisters or ripping their hearts out both of which lead to two rather unsatisfying endings... I fell in love with the atmosphere and the setting, but I can't do more than just feel sad that it's just a shooter - and the shooting part feeling much more like Oblivion, the gunplay representing a very weak part of the game as a whole. Some of the Plasmids were cool, but once again - I found myself using only 2 or 3 for the most part since a lot of the abilities they give are just either ruled out by your playstyle or simply poorly balanced and totaly useless. The difficulty is also another issue. You litteraly have no need to put it on Hard more or Medium because you automatically respawn in a Vite-Chamber after your Hit Points are gone. What that means is that you don't have to use your health pack  -"First Aid Kits"because you can simply kill enemies through perseverance as it doesn't alter their health.  For this reason I found myself just rushing through the game on Easy, as the only thing that Medium and Hard consumes is your real-world time spent on the walkthrough. I definately advise you to try it, but not at full price. And definately don't expect a revolution - it has good voice acting, unique setpieces in it's narative - which seem to be painfully familiar with System Shock 2 and rather intriguing characters - yet it's far from perfect as critics claimed it to be...

												Favorite game 1 million/10Even though I put the game down so many times because I did not want to relearn it, I still loved it. The tension in this game is so good not to mention the chills you feel searching these abandoned halls of a once wealthy dystopia. For once I see a shooter that has an amazing story and it shows how much lack lust things have become. This game might not be perfect but it did something games rarely do for me. It made me feel and that is odd when you don't feel anymore, it left me speechless if it can do that for me then it might do it for you as well. Now I was spoiled a little from a few YouTube videos on the storyline but it still even with spoilers had a huge impact on me like getting hit by a bullet train. Now the game play made my heart race, that never happens that function in my brain was broken a long time ago and it worked. The last time a game had this huge amount of an impact on me was fallout 3 mostly because I got to see my character grow up and left more questions about my virtual parents  than answers. This one if you do the good ending you actually feel like a hero. Now unlike many other games with more than one ending the cause for the bad ending is something that you know is wrong from the start, unlike other games that ask you to put the work into doing some long quest exploring the map and finding secrets, you know how to get the good ending from the beginning . The mechanics are a little tricky that's why I did not pick it back up I had to put it down because life happened and I did exactly what I did with portal 2 and forgot to finish the game.I am glad I did, I actually came close to tears but still I am speechless this game will forever have a long lasting impact on me.The game play reminds me of half life if half life had more of struggle with ammo and required you to know thy enemy rather than shoot thy enemy with gun and take his ammo. You must learn this new environment and all it holds conserve ammo and modify your genes to allow you to better fight against the enemy.Though a warning a lot of people are complaining that it does not work with newer hardware unless you tweak it a lot. But it's from 2007 usually games from 2007 have issues with newer hardware, but there is a remake coming but I don't think it will be better than this one.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Bioshock is one of those games you can't help but to put in a category all by itself. It is not just an FPS, it is a narrative driven game where the story will take center place, and where the gameplay just seems to be the addition to that same story. I can't tell the plot without spoiling it to anyone, but I will tell you this, it is a story so good, with plot twists that will blow your mind, that at some point Universal Pictures was going to produce a movie based on it. The whole game world sucks you in, you explore an underwater city called Rapture, after your airplane crashes in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean... and literally nothing in this game, story wise, is as it seems. I was really impressed with this AAA story, and if you like games that are not just about blowing stuff up(which Bioshock also has in spades) you will be looking at your screen in awe as you reach the end of the game. The story is simply put, phenomenal. Gameplay wise, Bioshock offers a lot of freedom. You have your standard weapons, like a machine gun, a grenade launcher and a Pistol, each with 3 different ammo types. This plays a key role in battle, as some ammo is more efficient in dealing with certain types of enemies. You also have access to a camera, allowing you to take pictures of your enemies to discover their weaknesses, and it is a really useful tool. On top of the weapons, you have Plasmids. Plasmids are genetically created abilities that allow you to deal even more damage to your foes. You have Winter Blast which freezes your enemies which you can then dispose of with a shotgun blast for example, Electro Bolt which deals electricity to your enemies and hostile machinery, and quite a few others. The plasmids are what makes your approach to battles more fun. You can use them in any way you see fit, and this is what truly makes the combat in this game stand out. You have near infinite possibilities to dispose of your foes, and combined with your tonics, (upgrades that allow your character to get stronger and allow certain actions in the game a lot easier) you can become a true killing machine. The AI in the game is quite impressive as well, with enemies running away when hurt, and looking for health stations to heal. These are some of the most challenging enemies in a video game I have ever encountered, and they will keep battles fresh and exciting. There is so much more I could say about this game, but the essential is this: Bioshock is one complete game package. The story is amazing, the gameplay is perfect and revolutionary, the music fits the action nicely, and even the graphics are really good, for a game with a few years. Bioshock is in my opinion, one of the best games ever made, and for the price you pay, you will be getting a game experience you will never forget.The Good-Amazing Story, it will mess with your definition of morality-Gameplay is fine tuned to perfection-The Plasmids offer a freedom in combat that is uncommon in FPS/RPG hybrids-Combat requires a cautious approach due to the ammo types in all weapons, simply point and shoot won't get you far-Art style is phenomenal, the city of Rapture has a very Art Deco feel to it-Characters in the game you actually care about(for the better and the worse)The Bad-Nothing I can think of, it is really close to perfection9.5/10

content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												A single-player only, story driven First Person Shooter with an imaginative setting and story. It took me 29 hours to beat it on hard, first try, 100% completion. If you're not as... thorough... as I am, then you ought to be able to beat it in 15-20 hours or so.I'd rate it pretty highly.BioShock puts you in the shoes of a survivor of a mid-ocean plane crash. With no where else to go, you swim to a nearby lighthouse but... why is it there?The game was designed for consoles so this is a PC-port. If you use a controller, you'll be in good hands. If you prefer the mouse and keyboard, then you'll probably want to fiddle with the .ini files in order to "fix" the mouse control. To do this, run the game once, and close it. Now, navigate to your documents folder and find the "AppData" folder. It is hidden so make sure you are showing hidden files in Windows. You're looking for the folder: [username]\AppData\Roaming\BioshockIn there, you'll find a user.ini and a bioshock.ini file. In the user.ini file find/add the following lines: (you can change the MouseAccelThreshold to 1.0 if you'd like some acceleration)MouseSmoothingMode=0MouseAccelThreshold=0.0 In the bioshock.ini file find/add the following lines: (they appear twice each, so make sure to set both to false)CaptureMouse=FalseReduceMouseLag=FalseDoubleBufferMouseLag=FalseIf the game ever crashes on you (which it will if you alt-tab or if you use the Steam overlay too many times), then these two files will be overwritten with a default file (bye bye custom controls =/ )To circumvent this, make a copy of these two files after you set up your graphics/sound/control options. If the game crashes, relaunch it, close it, and copy your backup files over the existing user.ini and bioshock.ini files to quickly restore your settings.Anyways, once your mouse settings are good to go the gameplay is great, and the story is engaging. If you haven't played this game yet then you're missing out. Have fun!

												You play as Jack (I had no idea this was the protagonist's name until I read it later) who never talks except for one line at the beginning intro. Your plane crashes next to a light house and you, for some reason, enter and explore Rapture.The game has too many bugs and crashes. If you look deep into Google enough, you'll probably solve them. But it's a little frustrating when you have to keep trying to find solution to all the crashing. The gameplay is really plain. It's your average shooter in a singleplayer game except you have some magic called ADAM. I found that a lot of the ADAM skills and other passive skills were not needed. I really only focused on just using guns, but that's just my playthrough of it. I felt the ADAM skills were only needed to stun enemies for a second. The real reason why I'd only recommened this game is for the story. A lot of times I was anxious and paranoid for any enemies that might be crawling around, but I also felt sad for them. I kept feeling depressed after hearing the recordings that are left behind by previous Rapture citizens, the Little Sisters, and especially Sander Cohen. Out of all the games I've played, this guy was the craziest yet funniest villains I've encountered.Overall: I have to give this 8/10The whole time I've kept asking myself as the protagonist, "Why the hell am I doing all this crap?" It's not until at the end when everything is revealed, which blew my mind. But there are too many pobrlems  with the crashing, the glitchy audio, and the mouse acceleration. However; I'd recommend this game for the lore and the environment. So would you kindly play this game?Also, I'd recommend you look wikipedia the history and story after finishing the game.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												I've never really thought much of this game. I bought it to give it a second chance. Let's take a look how good it was.Visually the game is good. The environment looks fine, but models are rather strange. Sounds are average, but the game has some nice songs playing from jukeboxes, radios etc. which fits the setting. Gameplay is quite awkward. Even though it has some good features (hacking, plasmids), the action itself doesn't work that great. Enemies run around like idiots, which makes them difficult to hit. You never have enough ammo, but you can buy that from vending machines. Weapons can also be upgraded, though effectivity of these upgrades is sometimes questionable. Sometimes the game tends to be frustrating, but mostly it's alright. But then comes one part where you keep losing your maximum health. It happens quite often, like every five minutes. Developers probably thought it was a good idea to punish you for exploring instead of rushing towards the goal to stop this health loss. They were wrong. Thankfully, you can explore what you missed later after you find a solution for this situation, and even your health gets back to normal.And the last thing to rate - the story. Hard to say anything about it since you hardly experience it directly. In order to get information about Rapture's past events, you must collect tape recorders and they slowly, like pieces of puzzle, let you see the whole picture. It's an interesting way to tell the story. The story itself seems above average.Even though it didn't get to the list of my most favourite titles, the game as a whole isn't bad. Rapture has a very original atmosphere and the architecture along with music makes the place feel alive. This game's weakest point is the gameplay, but it still is quite fun. Let's just hope the developers learned from some of their mistakes and polished the other two Bioshock games more.

content:

												Favorite game 1 million/10Even though I put the game down so many times because I did not want to relearn it, I still loved it. The tension in this game is so good not to mention the chills you feel searching these abandoned halls of a once wealthy dystopia. For once I see a shooter that has an amazing story and it shows how much lack lust things have become. This game might not be perfect but it did something games rarely do for me. It made me feel and that is odd when you don't feel anymore, it left me speechless if it can do that for me then it might do it for you as well. Now I was spoiled a little from a few YouTube videos on the storyline but it still even with spoilers had a huge impact on me like getting hit by a bullet train. Now the game play made my heart race, that never happens that function in my brain was broken a long time ago and it worked. The last time a game had this huge amount of an impact on me was fallout 3 mostly because I got to see my character grow up and left more questions about my virtual parents  than answers. This one if you do the good ending you actually feel like a hero. Now unlike many other games with more than one ending the cause for the bad ending is something that you know is wrong from the start, unlike other games that ask you to put the work into doing some long quest exploring the map and finding secrets, you know how to get the good ending from the beginning . The mechanics are a little tricky that's why I did not pick it back up I had to put it down because life happened and I did exactly what I did with portal 2 and forgot to finish the game.I am glad I did, I actually came close to tears but still I am speechless this game will forever have a long lasting impact on me.The game play reminds me of half life if half life had more of struggle with ammo and required you to know thy enemy rather than shoot thy enemy with gun and take his ammo. You must learn this new environment and all it holds conserve ammo and modify your genes to allow you to better fight against the enemy.Though a warning a lot of people are complaining that it does not work with newer hardware unless you tweak it a lot. But it's from 2007 usually games from 2007 have issues with newer hardware, but there is a remake coming but I don't think it will be better than this one.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Bioshock is one of those games you can't help but to put in a category all by itself. It is not just an FPS, it is a narrative driven game where the story will take center place, and where the gameplay just seems to be the addition to that same story. I can't tell the plot without spoiling it to anyone, but I will tell you this, it is a story so good, with plot twists that will blow your mind, that at some point Universal Pictures was going to produce a movie based on it. The whole game world sucks you in, you explore an underwater city called Rapture, after your airplane crashes in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean... and literally nothing in this game, story wise, is as it seems. I was really impressed with this AAA story, and if you like games that are not just about blowing stuff up(which Bioshock also has in spades) you will be looking at your screen in awe as you reach the end of the game. The story is simply put, phenomenal. Gameplay wise, Bioshock offers a lot of freedom. You have your standard weapons, like a machine gun, a grenade launcher and a Pistol, each with 3 different ammo types. This plays a key role in battle, as some ammo is more efficient in dealing with certain types of enemies. You also have access to a camera, allowing you to take pictures of your enemies to discover their weaknesses, and it is a really useful tool. On top of the weapons, you have Plasmids. Plasmids are genetically created abilities that allow you to deal even more damage to your foes. You have Winter Blast which freezes your enemies which you can then dispose of with a shotgun blast for example, Electro Bolt which deals electricity to your enemies and hostile machinery, and quite a few others. The plasmids are what makes your approach to battles more fun. You can use them in any way you see fit, and this is what truly makes the combat in this game stand out. You have near infinite possibilities to dispose of your foes, and combined with your tonics, (upgrades that allow your character to get stronger and allow certain actions in the game a lot easier) you can become a true killing machine. The AI in the game is quite impressive as well, with enemies running away when hurt, and looking for health stations to heal. These are some of the most challenging enemies in a video game I have ever encountered, and they will keep battles fresh and exciting. There is so much more I could say about this game, but the essential is this: Bioshock is one complete game package. The story is amazing, the gameplay is perfect and revolutionary, the music fits the action nicely, and even the graphics are really good, for a game with a few years. Bioshock is in my opinion, one of the best games ever made, and for the price you pay, you will be getting a game experience you will never forget.The Good-Amazing Story, it will mess with your definition of morality-Gameplay is fine tuned to perfection-The Plasmids offer a freedom in combat that is uncommon in FPS/RPG hybrids-Combat requires a cautious approach due to the ammo types in all weapons, simply point and shoot won't get you far-Art style is phenomenal, the city of Rapture has a very Art Deco feel to it-Characters in the game you actually care about(for the better and the worse)The Bad-Nothing I can think of, it is really close to perfection9.5/10

content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												Well... Where do I start? The story starts with you, on a plane which somehow crashed into the sea and near a lighthouse.. It seems you're the only one that survives the crash and having no choice, you went inside the lighthouse and found a bathysphere.. Looks good enough, when you came down and found out that you were going to an underwater city called rapture where at first glance looks like an utopia, but hides a more sinister background. Until here, I feel that the game follows the traditional line of FPS games. I have to admit, the graphics, music, and ambience was spot on. While those are factors that helps to improve game experience, I myself gave a higher emphasis on great story and plot rather than just aim and shoot. As the story progresses, you will make choices such as deciding whether to (Spoiler) harvest or save the little sisters. Either one of those choices would impact the gameplay in a way and also (Spoiler) the ending as well. Nevertheless, as you progressed, you realised that what you perceived as the truth... might not be the right one after all. After a quite lengthy process to reach what I thought was the end, instead I was given the shock of my life (Yes, that came out of nowhere). If you paid attention, you could see it happening, but you never thought it would be the crucial factor! Then came what I think is the weaker part of the game which are close to the end.. The boss battles was suprisingly not that difficult and the ending.. Well, even though I am glad my choices are correct, for some reason I wanted more (probably I hope I would get more explanation in Bioshock 2 and Infinite).To be honest, I've heard of bioshock but never had the chance to play it until it was on sale (3 games for 13$). But after I played it, this game basically was an eye-opener. I had played many FPS games and not one game, have such amazing combination of all the factors that made the game not just great, but also potentially I could call a cult classic. The game also introduced the music nicely, which opened my music sense to old songs from the 40s and 50s. Just like GTA opened my ears to spanish, classical, rock, rap, hip hop, and country music, this game allows me to listen and appreciate songs that baby boomers or traditional generations listen to.All in all, I would give this game 9.4 / 10. This was that gem, that rare find in the sea of mud where contrary to popular belief, FPS games can also have amazing storyline and plot while having (during its time) a unique combat system.This is easily one of my top 3 games of all time (which might change as I haven't played 2 and Infinite + the dlc!)Now, would you kindly buy and play this game?

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												Bioshock 1, the spiritual sucessor to System Shock and keeping most of the creepyness of its forefather intact. *SPOILERS PRESENT*Lets talk about the first thing we see in the game, the Graphics, the game just oozes with atmosphere and detail, when you walk around rapture you can see how people would live their lives, theres no randomly placed gap which would make you wonder how people got over it or why its there its modeled in a way that you'll walk around a place the same way you would if Rapture was real, and not falling apart, or have crazed looniees trying to kill you.That said there are a few low points about the graphics, some stuff feels VERY Copy and Paste, like i never enjoyed going into the bars because they felt too similar to each other, I might just be oblivious since I don't go to pubs in the real world but I would assume at least SOME differance also while I get this is meant to be a city that is collapsing from the inside but I think there is way too much grey around, its a typical gripe with FPS games in the last 10 or so years bit I still belive it to be a valid complaintNext the sound, Honestly I didn't find the music that good, thats not a bad thing though as the lack of music or the sound of old style music playing from old radios helps add to the atmosphere, I don't know if this is a glitch though but sometimes when there was alot of shooting and such random audio bits would cut off, a prime example would be when I fought the first "boss" of the game (not the Big Daddys) I had 2 Flying guns (Buzzers I called them) and a turret shooting at him, with an alarm going off and him shooting my buzzers, during the entire fight the turret and one of the buzzers would be shooting with no sound coming out, other times when grenades were thrown the Wistle sound would keep cutting out and starting back in, as I said it might be a glitch but still, Minor gripe, The voice acting is pretty well done as well though the lines are repeated a liiiiittle too much which can make the fighting a little grating to the earsThe Gameplay is your pretty solid run and gun kind of shooting game I played it on the hardest difficulty and I'm going to say right now, its too easy, the reason is because it is impossible to Game over unless your at the final boss, Got killed by a Big daddy? don't worry you respawned and the big daddy is at the same health it was when you died! it kills alot of that fear the game could have as your being hunter by a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off diversuit man and your down to your last sliver of health and EVE, While we're talking about Big Daddys and Difficulty its pretty dissapointing that on the case you have the Driller Big Daddy (Bouncer) but on the hardest Difficulty you face primarly Rivet gun Big daddys (Rosie) it doesn't help when actually the Rosies are easier to kill then the Bouncers, sure you can get two shotted by a Rosie but at least you can keep your distance and snipe them while dodgeing the bullts, I honeestly found fighting the Rosies the worst part of the gameplay and fighting the Bouncers one of the best, because your constantly back peddling from the Bouncer while he is slowing you and charging at you, one of my fondest memories in the game is when a Duel between me and one of the Few Bouncers in the game ended with us both killing each other when we charged at each other in Melee, Fondest memory with the Rosies? eh, taking control of them.So I'll talk a bit about the Plasmids too, to be honest they seem like a mechanic that wasn't fleshed out in time, I only ever used 3 Plasmids (except when the game forced me to use other ones to progress or for plot convinience) Shock, Big Daddy Hypnotise and the Swarm, Shock just so I could hack turrets, Big Daddy Hypnotise because it was fun and Swarm just so I could yell out "NOT THE BEES!" The Plasmids are just "there" I never had a reason to use them except of course For Fun, Hacking or Quoting Nicholous Cage (all of which worth it in my eyes, especially the last one) Outsid of that I pretty much felt there was no real use for them, No enemies weak to a certain Plasmid no Deus Ex style of using a Plasmid to get through a place. As for the Passive Plasmids again there was no real point in some of them, the only ones I generally wanted more of was the Hacking ones because as the game went on Hacking got so hard to the point where it was literly impossible to hack without a few hacking plasmids.So lets move onto the Hacking...Honestly it stars fun but it gets boring, like REALLY boring This was basically how my Hacking excitement went*Start of game*Sweet! i can hack these Buzzers and turrets to fight for me!*1/4 through the game*Well Lemmi hack this Vending Machine, Cause why not?*1/2 Through the game*urgh.....Boring*After the 1/2 point*Screw this, Autohacking tool!It just becomes so very dull that I was using my huge amounts of cash (Again because the game is too easy so i always had alot of cash) on Autohacking tools, and on the final chapter I just stopped Hacking the vending machines all together because it was so very very dullFinally the Story *AGAIN, SPOILERS*Honestly its a little bit all over the place but in a good way and ends mostly with closure, ok well except one, why the hell did your plane crash? but I digress the game does a good job at pacing the story up to the big Shyamalan style twist and makes Atlus a very beliveable friend which is all the more suprising at the end, Atlas as a character is a rather well developed character...untill near the end when he becomes Fontanie, he then spends the rest of the game mocking you from your com system and to degrade him even worse during the last hour I kid you not about an hour before you face him he suddenly becomes a spliced up looney, Personally that was weak because all it didn't feel like I was faceing the guy who set me up, i just felt like I was facing another Splicer Alibet a newer one, I would of liked a good ol fasion Gun duel and before you beat him he THEN pulls out a new plasmid he made to turn him into what he is to try and get the edge.Overall Bioshock is a well made game and has alot of atmosphere, gunplay, and likeable characters, the things I don't like about it though is how the main villian becomes a Splicer loony like the rest of Rapture, The hacking gets VERY boring and because you can only game over at the final boss its very VERY easy

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												Bioshock is my favourite FPS game. I wanted to play it to do a 3rd walkthrough just recently, but for some reason I could not make it run on Windows 7. I know there are some bug fixes, tweaks out there, but eventually, I decided not to bother with them. Initially, I played this back on XP and also on Vista as some of the effects required DX 10.What makes Bioshock a unique FPS game is its atmosphere. The protagonist finds himself in an underwater city called Rapture after an airplane crash which was meant to be a sanctuary, a safe haven from the atrocities of the world by its creator, but right at the beginning you quickly realise something went awry as almost all the inhabitants of this marvelous city want to kill you. And also each other. These residents are all obsessed with ADAM, a substance found deep under water. Or more like a substance that was extracted from slugs found in the dark, cold abyss. This substance grants its user superhuman powers, powers that are just like magic: you can set things on fire, you can grab and throw objects at your enemies, you can control machines etc. Clearly, humanity's greed got the better of it, again, as it seems everybody is set out to grab more and more ADAM to seize power. And what are those huge fellows called Bid Daddies who wonder around in thick armor escorting (protecting) little children (girls) who are characterised by two things: they have a huge syringe in their hands and their eyes are glowing.The game offers you conventional weapons found in any other FPS games but makes it more interesting as you have various types of bullets available at your disposal. And while you hold your weapons in your right hand at the same time you can cast your spells with your left hand. You can also hack things so that you can purchase items at vending machines with discount and in case you hack turrets or sentry bots you can quickly get some allies. In order to use your Plasmids (spells) you are required to get some EVE (similar to mana in many RPGs). It is inevitable  to fight Rapture's monstrous creatures called Big Daddies to get some ADAM with which you can purchase new Plasmids (or the better version of the one you already have).It's worth checking every room, every corner in Rapture as you can find some hidden treasures. Notable are the audio logs that expand upon the background story and you can get to know the main characters of the city better and also understand what their agenda is. The game has morality choices, too: although you fight Big Daddies the very reason you want to defeat them is to get close to the little girls they protect. You extract ADAM directly from them and you can decide whether or not you want to let them live. This means you can have two endings at the game.The game has a superb art design and lovely music. Its atmosphere can be creepy, scary at times and exploring Rapture is a fun experience between fierce battles. This is highly recommended to anybody out there who loves the FPS genre; bear in mind, though, that the game has issues with Windows 7 so it's best to look for the solution beforehand.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
~ We all make choices, but in the end, our choices make us. ~I played BioShock once on the PS3 a few years back and I remember not loving it that much. I really liked the first half, but I found the second half to suffer from pacing issues. Flashback to a few weeks ago and my backlog was running dry, so I decided to replay it, this time on PC. And you know what, I'm not sure why I didn't love it the first time around, because this is one incredible game. It nails pretty much every aspect you'd want in a game. The setting is nothing less than brilliant, Rapture looks visually stunning and it never gets old, the atmosphere is absolutely stellar and the creepy 30s music give it a sinister feeling, the story and characters are really something else and the gameplay is very diverse and encourages experimentation. But the best thing about BioShock is how fleshed out Rapture feels, especially when you replay it and you keep noticing new things that you didn't see or hear the first time.  In terms of story there's so much lore in there it's almost ridiculous, if anything it's overwhelming at first. I'm not going to tread into spoiler territory, but only in subsequent playthroughs do things start to make sense, which really adds to a city that already feels so alive.+ Excellent visual design, Rapture looks absolutely gorgeous.+ Haunting and claustrophobic atmosphere with creepy music from the 1930s.+ Very tense and sometimes even scary at points.+ Ridiculous amount of background information and lore.+ Very solid, fun and diverse gameplay, lots of play styles and experimentations possible.+ A lot of memorable and varied characters.+ Pretty much perfect voice acting from everyone involved. - A few technical issues here and there, some crashes and freezes when loading a new area.- I didn't like the last playable level (Proving Grounds. There were barely open areas to explore which made all the other levels so much fun, it was basically a straight line to the final battle.- The endings (both good and evil) felt too rushed and, even though satisfying in a way, it doesn't feel fleshed out whereas the main game definitely feels fleshed out.9/10

Posted: February 8, 2015
												A classic that I've never played before it's steam release and I'm here to say it's still worthy of most the praise it gets.I'll keep it short.GOOD+Story is fantastic. Many hours of gameplay for a single player game. Even has replay value.+The FPS elements are great. Using different guns and abilities to take out your enemies doesn't get stale.+The RPG elements aren't perfect but can really change the way you play, especially when you start upgrading.+ Even though through most of game the tension is high and it can be downright scary at times, it was never grotesque or resorted to jumpscares to shock you.+ Difficulty modes. The game might be a bit overwhelming at first but is actually rather easy when you get used to it. But being able to increase the difficulty on subsequent playthroughs solves that problem.+ Though the visuals might have aged somewhat, I got totally emersed in them.NOT SO GOOD- Controls aren't optimal and is part of the overwhelming start. Switching weapons, powers and ammo doesn't get smooth until you learn to just deal with it.- The Hacking minigame, like in most other games, is too boring and occurs way too frequently. Almost every camera and turret in the game needs to be either hacked or destroyed to progress. And since conserving ammo is quite a big deal, hacking is the best choice but also the most boring one.-Though survival and conserving your ammo are elements of the game, expect to blaze through on easier difficulties after you get used to the enemies and such. (Big Daddies are Big Babies, no really)- The final araes of the game take a looong time. This might be a good thing to some, but it feels stretched and a little disjointed from the rest of the game. Making the ending overall a bit weak compared to all you've done to get there.So step right up and get yourself a ticket to Rapture, because this game is totally worth playing! Especially if you've become a fan of the Bioshock series because of it's more recent installments!

Posted: July 3, 2016
												Bioshock is a first-person, sci-fi, fictional shooter where you take the role of Jack, a normal person at the beginning of the game soon to become one of the most iconic figures in both this game and the entire Bioshock series. You must traverse the underwater so-called "paradise" of Rapture, where those who dwell in it are free from religious criticism against their own ideas, free from the restraints of government, and are free to pursue their own ideals, to take down the rebellious tyrant Frank Fontaine.I have to admit, when I first started playing this game back in 2010, I had my doubts. Why? Because for me, violent videogames wasn't so much my cup of tea, in fact, back then I never really played violent videogames; I usually played Mario. But after playing this game twice, TWICE, both on PC in 2014 and PS3 of 2010, this game has made me a huge fan of the Bioshock series because the story is insanely rich, dark, driven, and deeply fulfilling, packed with violence, betrayal, and revolution. And the entire setting in general: an underwater city, who ever thought of that? You can think of Atlantis, but heck, not this one!To start off, the start of the game where you're in the plane seems to bring about curiosity as to what this game really is about, because you can look at the front cover of the game and say, "Hey. It's a man in a diving outfit, and he's with a little girl. Well that's pretty cool." However, I usually say that covers can be illusions to what lies behind, and for Bioshock, this is 100% correct. Already do you crash land in an ocean somewhere off the North Atlantic ocean, near Iceland, swim to some very imposing and unknown, yet beautiful and intricate, building, enter inside, go into a bathysphere (a ship-thingy), and already you're in Rapture. What better way to already jump into the dark, underwater "paradise" then crash-land, swim, then witness the city first-hand through a metal sphere?Now, aside from that, Bioshock is a first-person shooter, and it does that well. However, what makes this game unique in it's POV is that you fight with genetic weapons called Plasmids, made from a genetic resource known as ADAM, which serve as your primary utility throughout the game. Rather than say, "Okay, this guy's got magic for some reason," you can say "The guy's a severely altered, genetic freak, so kick your heels and run!" It's interesting to see a game where the magic is the result of genetic mutations and self-splicing alterations rather than some natural, innate gift because it really brings about that gruesome background of the game... and teaches kids why you shouldn't use drugs.Anyways, the story, damn! I played this game four times and not once did I get bored with the story. It is huge, and while repetitive, it is great, and it never dries up, it never goes dull, and it always stays alive. The whole foundation of the game itself is heavily dependent on its story because it is the story that sets the game in a momentous rhythm that will leave you wanting more. From how Rapture fell during the Civil War of 1959, to the remains and its genetically-altered denizens and future impact is so well woven and produced that I could not imagine a better game story that can compete against this one.The enemies in this game that you fight against are very creative, different, genuine, and, of course, unique. Big Daddies,   altered humans in diving suits who have been heavily spliced and grafted into their suits are a true challenge to face, but enjoyable to fight against. Splicers, possessing different types of abilities through the overdose of ADAM and Plasmids, makes the game more intense as you have to come up with different ways to fight them off or run away.Truly, the best thing about this game is the entire environment and setting itself. When I saw Rapture through my own TV screen for the first time, I thought that this was perhaps the most amazing creation in a videogame I've ever witnessed. An underwater city that isn't a utopia, has a different name, and can no way be related to Atlantis really brings about the unique quality of Rapture and makes it stand preeminent amongst all other underwater myths. While shocked, I was also awestruck by Rapture's own beliefs and ideals set forth by its philosophical leader Andrew Ryan, because normally, people would just create a history for a city, but this is a whole new level of "history," filled with insanity and dark athmospheres.Overall, all I can say about this game is:🐅Snowy's Scorey🐅:10: Masterpiece, highly recommended to play9: Truly brilliant, recommended at its best8: Okay, will recommend7: Decent, will recommend, but within certain limitations6: Average, probably not worth recommending, but at least looking at5: Meh, some things are right, some wrong, but not complete4. Um.., not sure if this game is up for grabs3. Not worth buying2. Not worth looking at1. Quarantine yourself from this gameAlthough the graphics are not exactly perfect, who freaking cares? The game itself is a masterpiece, with a heavily-driven story, cool combat mechanics and environment, and the lavish and beautiful setting of underwater Rapture. Buy this game when HD Remastered comes out in September because I can guarantee you this game will be amazing. The game is definitely worth the price, and it is entertaining all around.

												This GAME!!! I shied away from it for a long time as I detest most shooter type games feeling that good suspense and horror is based on story and powerlessness of the main character.... WARNING: Now, first of all, I do have to say (and this shall not detract from my overall opinion of the game in the review itself), I had TONS of trouble trying to get this darn game to work. I never got it to work on Windows 7, despite following all common proceedures (running compatibility modes and certain launch parameters etc.). And after a solid three days of trying to get it to work, and it still refusing to run, I then went to try and run it on a Windows 8 laptop, and hey-ho, it worked! So just a warning, purchasing this on Windows 7 may prove to be quite a bit of a gamble, unfortunately. I hear some people work it perfectly, while others, not so. Anyhow, the game was eventually working, and so our journey begins:-------------------------One of my main concerns with the the first Bioshock, upon purchasing the Bioshock Triple Pack was, "Will it still hold up today, in 2015 - nearly 8 years after release - even after I  completed the near-flawless Bioshock Infinite, just a few days before?". It's simple. The answer is: HELL YES, GOOD SIR/MA'AM.Rapture (now probably one of my favourite game settings EVER! (I still must play Stalker, mind you! :3)) captures your full attention from start to finish. If you're anything like me, and you find yourself intrigued by the prospect of dystopian societies (whether that be through: 1984, Terminator, Brave New World and whatnot), you will love Bioshock. The true nature of Rapture really shines through, with the presence of audio logs, scattered around the game, which provide tons of insight into the fascinating city, all on top of the brilliant linear story Bioshock presents.THE NARRATIVE: (9.99/10)I usually hate collectibles in games, seeing that they mostly provide little incentive, other than some measly achievement, or a disappointing extra cut scene. But Bioshock somehow makes it worthwhile! It certainly helps that it all has top-notch voice acting, lots of really interesting back-story in how Rapture came to be (and then not be), and also, if you listen carefully, great links to the overall linear story of the game. At first, the audio logs have an uncomfortable overall  aroma of optimism, despite you knowing what the city ultimately becomes. And the way in which you hear the people recording the audio logs progressively lose their minds is equally sad and unsettling. Even the enemies you gun down become somewhat sympathetic, despite Rapture essentially being a society whereby the smartest, the richest, and the cockiest are all clumped together underwater - all while forgetting any sense of moral values, that are thought to 'plague' the world above.In terms of the linear story, I will admit that it's major purpose is to build up to one 'twist', about 2/3 of the way through the game, and this is one twist that arguably could define the entire game, in terms of its legacy. For me, this twist was spoiled approximately 2.3 billion times before I actually played the game, but, I still enjoyed it nonetheless! As although it seems rather unremarkable and unpredictable, the context is everything. Not to mention the mind-blowing way it is delivered, and one that is sure to top some of my favourite ever moments in video games. Do try very hard not to get it spoiled though, that is, please don't research the plot on Wikipedia. You won't regret it. :) That all being said, unfortunately, don't be expecting any equally revolutionary ending of the game, as it is rather underwhelming and predictable. (Especially with a slightly out of place end-boss fight) Which is a huge shame! Although I do suppose Bioshock is often cited as one of the greatest games, with the worst endings.COMBAT/GAMEPLAY: (9/10)The combination of using plasmids (genetically modified, almost 'magic' abilities, that allow you to do various disgusting things with your hands), and weapons is quite fun. Although, it may initally appear a "step-back", for those that played Infinite first, like I did, or Bioshock 2 (although God Only Knows why you'd play that before the previous instalment), since those games allow you to use both weapons and plasmids at the same time. Whilst in Bioshock 1, you must use the right mouse button to switch between them. Do not fear, because you get quite used to it.'Bioshock' does have one thing going for it though, and that's the sheer variety of ways you can use its combat mechanics to your advantage. I still struggle to choose what I found most satisfying to do, but I believe there's probably a playstyle for just about everyone in the game somewhere. For instance, you'll often be found in a situation whereby there's a large group of enemies, and you have a whole arsenal of plasmids and weaponry to accompany you. You could just telekinesis the explosive barrels at a group of splicers, and ignite any remnants of oil on the floor to prevent them getting to you. Or you could hack into a disabled turret to help take them out for you, and set explosive and electrical traps to keep them at a distance. Maybe you just want to silently bash them over the head and freeze them solid? You got it. It's not quite Deus Ex, or Dishonoured, but it's probably about as close enough as it gets.One particularly interesting enemy was the highly memorable, 'Big Daddies', which I don't want to get into too much detail about. But oh boy, they're pretty tough. The Bouncer' quick reflexes, charges, and the shockwaves it unleashes make things really interesting, and it constantly keeps you on your toes. As you scurry around the surrounding area, thinking of ways you could make your life significantly easier at that very moment of time.  I have heard many complaints regarding the ammo and loot distribution being a bit unbalanced, especially further into the game, as some people believe that some of the tension is rendered a bit pointless when you're absolutely loaded with first aid kits and bullets. While I can see where those people are coming from, I personally didn't have much of a problem, as I often enough, found myself in situations where I had to conserve my ammo somewhat if I wanted to make progress. Mind you, there's probably room for improvement, but it didn't bother me that much. SOUND: (10/10)Moving on, sound design: PHENOMENAL. I really do dig games which evoke incredibly bone-chilling atmopsheres (eg: Dead Space, Metro 2033, Alan Wake). But I believe Bioshock to currently be my favourite of them all (again, I'm yet to play Stalker. :P). And a huge contributor to Bioshock's amazing atmopshere is the way sound is used to really amplify moments of tension: The distant shrieks, screams and complaints of splicers, the unforgettable stomps of the 'Big Daddies', the gurgling and gushing water, the creaks of the dying architecture of Rapture, and various other things... And when it's all combined with quite effective use of lighting, and a soundtrack that pays perfect tribute to the sheer insanity of Rapture's citizens: Bioshock becomes a masterpiece.  The game is not particularly 'scary' per say, but the atmosphere is built in such a way, you'll trick yourself into constant paranoia. And I loved every minute.CONCLUSION:I have no idea how I had not managed to get around to playing the Bioshock series sooner, but I can assure you, I've been missing out on a lot. Even if you're only remotely interested in the game/series, you should give it a good shot. The first game in particular will always stand up there with all my favourite games of all time. And in my humble opinion, masterpieces don't have to be absolutely perfect, and I am willing to forgive the few flaws I have found with Bioshock, because it is just that good. I think it's a masterpiece. And (apologies for the cliche'), a must-play.It's so tempting to give it a 10/10 overall, so I just think I will... Just excuse the ending? :P

												After hyping up BioShock for a long time, expecting it to be System Shock 3. I was VERY dissapointed.The gameplay felt dumbed down and there was absolutely no relation story wise (except for some similar elements).So I stopped playing it, and left it for about 6 years (not even kidding).I returned to it last year with a fresh pair of eyes, knowing it has nothing to do with System Shock and is it's own thing.The gameplay was not as bad as I thought and is quite in depth. The enemies are varied and interesting. And a fair amount of weaponry is available to dispatch them. Each one can be upgraded and can be used in unison with plasmids and tonics to create deadly combos.But where it really shines is the story, characters, setting, art, lore, concepts and atmosphere. It is AMAZING. It all comes together to make a truly immersive and terrifying experience. And should be considered to be an artistic masterpiece. I can't recommend this any more. Play this in the dark with headphones and soak it in.Edit:However the ending leaves something to be desired.

												BioShock. What can I say.This game is without a doubt in the running for game of the generation. For years prior to this game, the industry had been slipping out of the fact that games must tell a story, and focused more on how they played and esentailly how much money they can make. Then along game BioShock, the spiritual successor to System Shock 2, a game which would change the way we tell stories in games forever.Packed in with its superb story, comes a uniqe horror-esq experience that I have only felt in BioShock. The atmosphere in this game is so fantastic, you would believe a city could actually be underwater. BioShock correctly displays the corruption of a once bold empire, and the impact it has had on life under the sea. The main character, Jack, is shrouded in mystery for most of the game until "it" happens...10/10. The 6th entry in my 10/10 hall of fame. Play the game.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												This game is a piece of art. It's a masterpiece. However, the gameplay itself isn't what makes the game special to me. What makes the game truly amazing is the atmosphere of the world. The levels are so detailed. You can learn so much about the history of the world just by observing advertisements on the walls and listening to audio tapes scattered across the world. The story is so unique. The lore of this game is what's going to keep me coming back for more. There are many plot twists that will shock and amaze you. The gameplay isn't anything amazing or innovating. It's a first person shooter full of your normal: revolvers, machine guns, shotguns, grenade launhers. But the game also includes superpowers called: plasmids. These really keep the game fresh and exciting as you can do anything from emitting electrcity from your hands or using telekinisis to lift dead enemies and use them as a human shield. Overall, the gameplay is really fun and addictive and is a great complement to the amazing atmosphere, story, and world of Bioshock. 10/10

Posted: June 24, 2015
												I don't know how to write this review without giving out spoilers, but I shall try.I bought this game after playing Bioshock Infinite, of course expecting the same beautiful visuals, story-line and characters.Wasn't disappointed, but... since the city of Rapture is underwater as opposed to suspended in the sky, there were some stark differences, one of which is obviously the lighting and atmosphere, it's all so eerie and creepy, with a decent number of jumpscares.The first 5-6 hrs of the game were an utter bore to me, I was struggling with my Eves and First Aid Kits, kept running out of ammo, it was tricky to switch between the plasmid and your weapon mid-fight, and the freaky atmosphere wasn't doing anything to make me feel better. But after that, it was all uphill, I started seeing the reason why I bought this game in the first place, the story picked up, it was paramount to solve the current mission and move on to the next ASAP.Gameplay wise, it is decent, but what really is the heart and soul of the game is the story and the morality of your choices. I chose badly, thinking there was no other option and will always be haunted by my choices. The ending was quite emotional and a real kick in the gut. The game did crash a couple of times though...The Bioshock franchise has a knack for brilliant story-telling, and now, would you kindly buy the game and see for yourself. =)

Posted: June 20, 2014
												What can I say about one of the most thought provoking games created in the 21st Century? One of the Master classes of FPS, BioShock combines exciting FPS gameplay, with a tense storyline, and brutal social commentary. For years I had waited for someone to do a refutation of Atlas Shrugged by the radical nut Ayn Rand. Finally I have been given something of that caliber. One of my favorite aspects of this game is its use of the Art Deco movement to define the architecture of the beautiful Rapture. Art Deco is one of my favorite art forms and to see it in a video game is just brilliant. Ken Levine is a master storyteller who isn't afraid to get his hands dirty in the mud pool that is political commentary. One of the greatest art works of our generation.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Who’s the Big Daddy?BIOSHOCK is a fine example of what is achievable through the medium of video games. The developers have managed to combine an engaging story with strong RPG and FPS elements to produce a thoroughly absorbing and memorable experience. The storyline is unusually effective and all the more compelling due to the aspects of morality it addresses. The voice acting is terrific, especially the chuntering splicers that wander around Rapture -- their psychotic ramblings are utterly convincing. The game is also graphically impressive for a 2007 production -- Rapture is a beautiful, art deco wreck of a city. There could perhaps have been more humour, but overall this is one of the best single-player games I’ve played.5/5

												PORTUGUESE REVIEWBioshock conseguiu ser de longe um dos melhores jogos que já joguei em toda minha vida. Sem dúvidas é um investimento que compensa horas de diversão. O jogo tem uma trama muito envolvente, rico em detalhes e com um ar de mistério do qual deixa o jogador em total imersão. A história de Bioshock é baseada em uma utopia dos anos 60, e mantém-se fiel aos mínimos detalhes da época. Fora todo o contexto histórico da época, o jogador tem de encarar humanos transformados pelo vicio em Plasmids, os colossais Big Daddies e capturar ou libertar as Little Sisters, sem falar que as ações do jogador influenciam no final da história, sendo certo ou errado, caberá ao jogador decidir.ENGLISH REVIEWIn my opnion it is absolutely sure that Bioshock is one of the best games ever due to its rich details, the awesome story, and of course, the suspense involving the whole game. Despite of all the difficulty, Bioshock still such an awesome game no matter what type of gamer you are. You will enjoy it for sure! But be aware, your actions in the game can inffluence in different endings. It is up to you what you think about 'right' or 'wrong' actions. Have fun!

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
Positive:Tight story-driven gameplay and narration similar to Half-Life 2 and the likes.High level of detail and thoughtful level design. Some assets are used repeatedly and some special characters could have deserved more individual ingame models to make them stand out from the regular NPC, but all the levels, their layouts and their assets make sense. Everywhere you look you can see something special or unique rewarding those who look closer. There is some nice sound design too - your shoes squeaking on metal surfaces, the moaning of the Big Daddys, the sounds of whales or something like that whenever glancing outside into the depths of the Atlantic. Even when walking completely barred down areas you still know you are in a deep underwater city at the edge of collapse with water constantly leaking here and there, hitting you from above, washing down your vision and distorting it. I don't think an underwater city could be designed more believable and ambiance-strong than in Bioshock.What I noticed positively in comparison to Bioshock Infinite:- Enemies do respawn a bit. It makes the city feel more alive. In Infinite they would never respawn. Had you killed every enemy in the latter all the areas you were in remained empty. Not so in Bioshock. This also encourages playing around with guns or plasmids (special powers). - Enemies react more with their surroundings. Mildly. Like interacting with health stations to regenerate health, or standing in front of some item booths swearing at then to be broken or something. I never noticed anything like that in Infinite.- The Big Daddys and their Little Sisters are not enemies per-se. If you don't attack them they will not harm you either. This is rather unlike to how these straightforward story-driven shooters usually work. There wasn't really anything like this in Infinite either.Undecided:If you play on a too low difficulty, or if you are skilled enough with shooters, you may not find much use in the many plasmids and tonics that enhance your combat powers or that give you passive perks to avoid cameras, sneak up more easily on enemies, photograph them with better scores or whatever. I played on the easiest difficulty. I basically went guns blazing through the game and kept using like only three guns out of six or seven or so, and only two or three plasmids out of nine or so. The tonics I never really cared about too much either. Some enemies are resistent to some plasmids, and the game at one point "forbids" you to use some plasmids; while that was explainable story-wise it felt a bit forced. Still, all of these "gadgets" felt better implemented than in Bioshock Infinite (where it felt a bit silly at what rate and numbers they were tossed at you). I skipped hacking many booths and safes too because there was no need to buy anything (ammo, supplies, power upgrades) or because I always had enough automatic hacking tools with me.  If one wants to see more sense in the "whole picture" of this gadget/"economy"/resource management thing I suggest trying one of the harder difficulties or one may end up ignoring/skipping most of what is there.The same as in the previous paragraph applies to roaming levels for supplies. All items are uniquely placed around, that is part of the "high level of detail" I mentioned, and one may find that interesting and fun enough, but if you play on easy difficulty and/or if you are skilled with shooters there is little need to loot all the various containers and look in all the corners to find supplies. You simply won't need most of them. Even if you do it can become a one-button hitting spamfest because you will always want to grab most of what there is anway for the lack of any inventory whatsoever. What you can't grab the game will just leave where it is. I personally decided to just spam my "use" button at everything that could have possibly been a container rather than actually pay attention to what was in there. The only thing I genuinely cared about when looting around where the audio tapes from the various special characters in the game that would give insight into the recent history of Rapture. I did search all corners I became aware of just to see the way the devs placed their assets, but that aside there was little point to it.Negative:Characters could have deserved more depth. Some of them at least. Andrew Ryan was the most interesting one, but all the others are rather one-sided and predictable in what they want and do and think.Gunplay felt awkward, or a bit sloppy. I didn't try changing sensitivity or something but aiming didn't feel as easy as in other shooters. Not even when aiming down the sights. On the contrary I found it always easier to fire my guns from the hip. The gunplay didn't feel as bad as for example in Left 4 Dead, but not as great as in more modern semi-military FPS either.Animations of ragdolling character models and items looked odd. Not as "fluently" as one may expect. Like when shooting down an enemy from the ceiling he would fall down thanks to gravity and all, and ragdoll along the way just fine, but kinda like in some half-working slow-motion or something. Really hard to explain.There are three endings. I've seen the others on YouTube. I was satisfied with mine, but others may find theirs disappointing or irritating because the choices on which it depends what ending you get may not feel as obvious or logical as they should. Don't know if it's just me, but there were some bugs. Nothing too dramatic, but mildly annoying. I suppose related to the age of the game. I couldn't always hear all sounds. Like when I was shooting around the music would sometimes cut off for an extremely brief moment, the second I was to stop shooting (or my enemies) it would be there again. Then sometimes the game wouldn't always save my control and gameplay settings. The default key assignments in Bioshock felt a bit odd (like running/walking is on CTRL rather than SHIFT) and so I sometimes had to reassign the buttons again when I was starting up the game again. I noticed the game wouldn't quit properly - when exiting it my Windows 7 would tell me about an unexpected error forcing to close down the application. It didn't hurt me directly because quitting the game was my intention, but this half-baken shutdown may be related to settings not being saved properly.What I noticed negatively in comparison to Bioshock Infinite:The protagonist is completely silent and unnamed. I did like the actively talking Booker in Infinite more, I generally prefer a talking protagonist in games more. It just feels odd and irritating and somewhat ambiance-breaking to see NPCs constantly avoid naming such one protagonist all the time or answer their own questions because the protagonist would never raise his own voice to do so.

Posted: June 9, 2015
												Bioshock:Positives:+ There is a really engaging story in Bioshock with a twist that you won't expect. Audio logs which supplement the plotline can be found by exploring the environment and are a welcome addition. The game is set in the underwater city of Rapture and follows two men who struggle for power - Andrew Ryan, leader of the famous Ryan Industries and Frank Fontaine.+ There are quite a few weapons that can be upgraded, like crossbows, shotguns, pistols, the Tommy Gun, grenade launchers and a chemical thrower which fires liquid nitrogen, napalm and electric gel.+ A key part of Bioshock is the use of Plasmids, genetic abilities which can freeze enemies solid, incinerate or electrocute them. Unleash a swarm of killer insects or create a decoy target to draw fire away from you. There's many options here.+ To add greater complexity there are tonics which improve your skills in countless ways. Physical tonics add healing benefits and eve restoration (eve is required to cast plasmids), engineering tonics are crucial to hacking safes, door combinations, gun turrets, vending machines and cameras. Then you've got combat tonics for physical damage resistance.  + The characters are interesting, the shooting is great, basically it's fun which is the most important pro.Mixed:~ Only about 15 hours of content for this FPS, which is not much (played on medium difficulty and didn't really have any issues). It's not the worst I've seen but clearly it's lacking in gameplay longevity. ~ Graphics are not bad considering the age of this game. Average.~ Somewhat linear game. It is not open-world and there are no side missions, it's strictly one area to the next. With that said, it's forgiveable since the developers have put some sort of effort into hidden areas and locations which aren't essential.Negatives:- Very poor map design, confusing to navigate and find out where to go for your next objective. Overall Score: 8/10Very much recommended!

Posted: July 21, 2014
												A steam punk horror FPS that will leave your jimmies quite rustled. Bioshock is the first game introduced into what would later become one of the best non-conforming FPS games to date. Filled with many twists and turns that will surely leave you scratching your head and really bringing the undersea world of Rapture to life. Bioshock is an intriguing title that tries, and sometimes fail, to spook you at every turn. The rusted and dilapidated environment accompanied with the pitter-patter of water hitting the  iron-clad walls and floor will bring the city of Rapture to life. An exhilarating story with many M. Night Shyamalan twists that really make the player sit down and think about what has happened through their experience in Rapture. A game that definitely has a story with a punch, but with some lacking basic fundamentals you'd expect to find in a FPS. Unfortunately, Bioshock isn't the best FPS for a number of reasons including difficulty when using spray (it's better to use guns as if they were semi-automatic for accuracy), a lot of the enemies move in strange ways that will cause them to complete dodge your shots if they're a certain distance from you (makes it very difficult unless you're aiming low when they are meleeing), and worst of all your only melee weapon is garbage even with all of the upgrades equipped. This makes medium to long range fights the best for you but there's constantly something running at you in your face. The FPS mechanics do take some getting used to and are pretty interesting, the fact that you don't zoom with right mouse button but with Z is definitely something most FPS don't do. Over the years the graphics have held up very well too and at the time of it's release it was hailed for it's intense computer requirements (thankfully much easier to acquire now). Bioshock is a title that deserves respect and while it's not fundamentally the best game the story is worth at least one trip though.☆★★★★ Overall ☆★★★★ Gameplay ★★★★★ Story ☆★★★★ Graphics ☆★★★★ Sounds ☆★★★★ Oddity ☆☆★★★ Length

												This game, to me, is the embodiment of a horror-action-shooter. It is a great game with many different ways to play and explore. I really enjoyed the diaries since they helped give me more nackground on the story, and they didn't get in the way at all, which is good. The combat is very stacked against you in some cases, but thats great. A challenge in any videogame is a good one. For example, when you run out of ammo, and cash, you need to rely on your sneaking around to get the jump on enemies. Not only is that difficult, but can be very rewarding. It is also noted that when you run out of EVE, you automatically become significantly weaker. This encourages scrounging, exploration to find more hypo or cash, or to sneak around, and try to avoid fights you could previously handle. With hundreds of different ways to play, its a groud breaking game. However, the ending in my opinion was a little fast. I played medium difficultly, and finished the fight in about 3 minutes. This is odd, since I would fight splicers that would take a very long time to kill, due to shortage of supplies and the fact that they would not die after multiple headshots. I feel they could've extended the boss fight slightly more, but thats not all the counts. The Journey is ultimately more fun and exciting than the ending, and it left me a hunger for wanting more. Great game, great mechanics, and would play again.

Posted: June 20, 2014
												The atmosphere in BioShock is stunning. The architecture of Rapture -- the underwater city where the game takes place -- is perfect, and through the game I found myself stopping to look through the windows, or at the buildings. The story is told by voice recordings and your interactions with NPCs, and the scenario is also a very powerful storytelling element. I played BioShock right after finishing Fallout: New Vegas, so I was in the mood for another dystopia set in a world with elements of the past.But BioShock is a shooter; and it's a very good one. The action is fast, controls are good, and there's lots of exploration. If you're like me, you'll enjoy exploring the levels to find every last item. Killing opponents is also a matter of choosing the right kind of gun and bullet, and/or plasmids -- which are powers given to you by modifying your genetic code.At the same time, BioShock feels a little like it was designed to be played with a controller. I prefer playing shooters using a mouse and keyboard combination, so switching between guns (which is done using the keys 1 through 7 in the keyboard) and plasmids (which is done using F1 through F6) was slow. You can press Shift to access a weapon choosing menu, and I did it more often than not, although it felt like cheating, since the game pauses. I just have to add that I'm not the best shooter player, so your mileage may vary.Also, BioShock gives you very little control over your character's choices. However, as I said, I played it right after Fallout, so I was very biased.Anyway, this game is great and I can't wait to play the second. Just buy it!

 Originally posted on May 25, 2009 Bioshock is an experience that will not leave me for years to come. From the very first few moments of the plane crash, to the first time you encounter a big daddy, to the confrontation with Ryan, and the completion of Cohen's masterpiece, Bioshock is simply amazing.First, visually it is stunning, even two years on. The art design, more than the technical graphics is absolutely astounding. That and the water looks incredibly real, and the feeling that everything is leaking is wonderfully atmospheric. The way the plasmids destroy your hand is fascinating, and seeing the decay in a once mighty utopia is something that words could never fully describe.The audio also greatly contributes to the game, with the audio diaries standing out in particular. Listening to them in order gives the player a wonderful and frightening picture of how Rapture tore itself apart. The side stories that the audio diaries give you a glimpse into create memorable and emotionally interesting characters that the player never actually meets. In fact, some of the most memorable characters in the game are already long dead by the time the player arrives. It is the reconstruction of their actions that is so fascinating.The Music, both composed for Bioshock (the score) and the period music that plays throughout Rapture is incredible. The pieces that you hear on jukeboxes and radios are classics that add to the atmosphere of Rapture as a time capsule greatly.The gameplay, from a shooter perspective is fun and varied, with many different types of enemies, and a good variety of weapons with upgrades and different types of ammo for each. In addition, you have plasmids and gene tonics, and various upgrades for them which really enhance the gameplay level. You can invent new ammo and tonics, buy supplies, and hack about any machine in the game, including turrets and bots to help you. There are so many ways to play that game that it can even be a little overwhelming at times, and it does tend to make the game a little too easy.Even so, Bioshock is an incredible experience, and even just for the story and exploring the environment, it is a must buy, and one of the most memorable games I've played in a while.

												None FPS fans read on!I am not, by any stretch of the imagination, a fan of FPS games.  They bore me to death in all honesty; so it was with some trepidation I gave Bioshock a go, having picked up all three games for a fiver in the Steam summer sale (can't go wrong for five quid, surely, I thought).I am pleased to say that Bioshock is a fantastic game. Instead I chose to creep around, hurling bees at the Splicers which was frankly as amusing the hundredth time to me as it was the first.The story is very good, boosted significantly by the environment, which makes you want more.  Having just finished the vastly inferior Bioshock Infinite I can in all honesty say that Bioshock is a one of a kind game; from stepping through those doors for the first time to the brief but satisfying (or not so much depending on your choices thoughout the game) ending, this is the kind of game that comes along once every so often and won't be repeated.Thumbs up, would shoot bees from hands again
