												**** DONT LET THE HOURS FOOL YOU, IVE COMPLETED THIS GAME 5+ TIMES ON ALL DIFFICULTIES ON CONSOLE, THE GAME JUST DOESNT WANNA RUN ON WINDOWS 10****** WILL CONTAIN SLIGHT SPOILERS **9 Years ago, we got Gears of War, Halo 3 and Call of Duty Modern Warfare. It was already a good year for gaming, but then you added Bioshock to the list. A game series that is still my favourite ever, and specifically a game that has been my favourite game of all time for a very very long time. I was 12 or 13 when this game came out. I was more in to the likes of Call of Duty or Gears, but my dad bought me this game for my birthday. I read up a little bit about the game before I started playing and wasnt happy to see it was a single player game with horror aspects.(Im a bit of a baby when it comes to horror games)Regardless, I put the disc in and hit play. This was the moment where a whole new world was opened up to me, Rapture,  Andrew Ryan, Atlas, Splicers and the whole messed up city under the sea. Why are these people so angry? Why do these little girls have glowing eyes? Why am I here?These were questions I had about 30 minutes in to the game.The story of rapture is so unique, and in depth that you wont learn a lot of the current history or lore while playing this game. You need to play Boshock 2 and Infinites DLC to figure out more (I also recommend the book Rapture: Bioshock by John Shirley, this is where youll learn the most about the history of the city under the sea and the people who made it to what it is now).LISTEN TO ALL THE RECORDING TAPES, THIS IS WHERE YOU LEARN SO MUCH ABOUT THE GAMES STORYThe game falls short for a lot of people when it comes to gameplay, and I find that arguable considering the game did come out 9 years ago. But I also think it is a fair thing to consider for new buyers or people looking to get in to the franchise. The combat is dull and simplistic in its own.But I think the fact that there are gun upgrades, plasmids (Plasmids give you different powers to use) and a variety of different ways to go around things when facing enemies, is enough to keep the game exciting when it comes to its fights.The atmosphre and visuals of this game are some of the best in gaming, ever. Bioshock has something of a trick to just make you feel as if you are there, in the world of Rapture. From gardens with poisonious plants, to freezing rooms where you have to melt walls of ice to progress, this game never failsw to make your FEEL your enviroment. Something a lot of games fall short on.The truth is...I cant find anything wrong with this game, its perfect. This game and this series are so special and incredible that I cant give it anything less than a 10/10. This world will amaze you. It will scare you. It will surprise you and it will sadden you. If you havent played this game of any in the series, please, I beg you, play them. This game is an absolute master piece and the other games fall from the same tree. Buy this game, play it, immerse yourself. I promise you 100%, you will not regret it.

AI was challenging, dodging shots, rushing you on, flanking.Plasmid selection was insane and they were fun to use. Looting and hacking was also very enjoyable. After a while game started to drag on, missions and tasks were tedious with all the do this and do that constantly, it felt like I was literally mind controlled in real life. Voice acting was good and enjoyable. Though I didn't enjoy much of the story, I still recommend this because some people might find it more entertaining than I did. 												Bioshock: System Shock 2... again. 8/10Seriously. The twist is the same, the characters are the same, the mechanics are the same (but simplified). Just felt like pointing that out... ON TO THE REVIEW!+The graphics look good to this day, with great water effects.+Amazing voice acting (the villain, as in the villain in the last quarter, is kind of over the top, but I think that that was intentional)+Good golden oldies soundtrack+Fun gunplay (mostly)+The plasmids/Psi powers/Vigors add a really fun dynamic to gunplay (even if half of them are useless) +The Art Deco designs are awesome.+Rapture is just a really cool setting.+Incredibly well written (you gotta love Andrew Ryan's rants, especially the ones nearer to his end. "A man chooses...")+Great commentary on the nature of gaming narratives that I won't spoil.-The final act of the game is just so awful. I feel like the game would have been twice as good if they had just ended with the twist reveal.-The Tommygun is so boring to use. This is a huge minus as it is the weapon with probably the most common ammo.-Speaking of which, the survival horor elements just feel token. At the beginning it is effective, but by the end, the lack of ammo just makes the game tedium. It is difficult to feel any sort of tension when there is no consequence to death (until the finale).-The final level of the game is an escort mission. A buggy escort mission. Enough said.-The final boss is awful. The developers (in an attempt to add tension presumably) made it so that you cannot save or respawn while fighting the boss. If you die, you are thrown into the main menu. The boss has three forms. All of them will kill you in two hits. This is not how you raise the stakes.-Both of the endings (this being an early 360/PS3 generation game has a pointless and simple morality system) are awful and abrupt. You are either a saint or the devil (despite the fact that the game actually tells you that the "EVIL" choice is good... but whatever).

Posted: September 17, 2015
												The spiritual successor to System Shock 2. Compared to System Shock 2 I think a lot of things got easier for player like we get the object arrow, no inventory management, easier resource management, no weapon degregation. Yet a lot of things changed for the better in a lot of ways. This game is super fun to play. You get to use all kinds of different strategies for defeating the enemies, be it setting up traps, turning them against each other, spells to stop them or just straight up blowing them up with different weapons. You also aren't really forced to stay on a path when it comes to that. You can constantly change the way you play on the fly, there's not really a leveling system that would need to be rerolled.I think the best thing about this game is in the atmosphere for sure. It feels like a real city. There's a lot variation too. Texture quality is good for the most part even for a game this old now. Not everything feels underwatery, but that is still the theme that repeats of course.What I really liked was the old school level design, like in Doom or something. There's a lot of secrets! If you just look to loot the enemies and some easy to spot safes you are missing a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of stuff! You really have to search for hidden doors, under the stairs, on the ceiling, on the bookshelfs. The devs really got good at hiding items from the player and trying to find everything was great.Sound design is excellent, you hear enemies talking behind corners all the time, saying really creepy♥♥♥♥♥♥ it's just awesome. Same with voice acting, excellent job by everyone. There's a LOT of audio recording in the world too so those who want to dig deeper about the issues in the city can do so. While those who just want to see gameplay and the major plot can skip all the recordings.Story and pacing is great. I hate super long cut scenes and long talks, not really the case here. There's not really many cut scenes. Everything is usually shown in the game world, a character appearing and talking to you or through the radio and I liked that approach a lot.If there's any negative about the game it's maybe the super simplified, black and white mechanics with little sisters. The game has 2 endings depending on your choice. The sort of grey area is missing, either you are a hero or you are not. I felt there should have been more choices throughout the game, like when you meet the citizens of the city- do you help them or destroy them? There could have been factions, side quests or something and multiple endings.Now the replayability is basicly on if you wanna see the other ending or not, which you probably should just youtube, since the game is so linear in that sense and you don't see anything new besides the 30sec ending video. Rather the replayability comes from the great gameplay, try different approach and difficulty setting, take more time to find the secrets, look at the level design, listen to the tapes.This game is easily 9/10 for me. If you end up liking this game a lot give System Shock 2 a try too, read the steam forums, update the textures and models a bit and it should still be a great game even today, That's what I did and liked it even more than Bioshock!

Posted: November 15, 2015
												I've only finnished this game yesterday and since then I've wanted to write a short review of it. Bioshock is a singleplayer, fps that sells itself on an interesting combat system and unique and complex story. The game is set in the fictional, underwater city of Rapture where a new scientific descovery has caused the citys enhabitents to go mad and murderous and become what are called Splicers. These will be your main enemy for the game along with security bots and Big Daddys as you explore, back-track ( theres allot of that) and then explore some more of the huntingly atmospheric Rapture.Now that i've mentioned the Big Daddys, they serve as optional bosses in the game. By killing them you can ether harvest or rescue the Little Sisters that they gard. If you rescue them then you get a small amout of adam (the currency for upgradeing your abilities) and the "good" ending. If you harvist them then you get lots of adam and the bad ending. But as i said you have to fight the Big Daddy to get these which serves as a nice risk and reward system.The story (no spoilers past the first hour) starts with your un-named silet protagonist's play crashing into Rapture. He is then aided by a man named Atlas who tells your character that in order to escape he must kill the cities founder Andrew Ryan.  Audio tapes reveal bits about the more advanced story. The story grabs you imediately and serve as one of the best parts about Bioshock... until about 2/3s of the way through the game. After an epic plot twist that i wont spoil the game in general becomes a sudden chore.After the twist the game throwes you into a long, boring fetch quest followed by one of the most hideous escort missions that ive ever played (if you hate this escort mission the you probably wont like Bioshock 2). Then there is an easy, anticlimactic boss fight followed by a TERRIBLE 30 second (if you get the good ending like me) cutscene. These missions, story choices acompanied by a huge difficulty spike make the last hour or so awful and boring.The combat system is fun though. You will use a combanation of wepons and plasmids (basicly superpowers) to defeat your enemies. Useing different combos of wepons and plasmids you can find awsome ways to kill people , for example, an electric shock and then a blast from the crossbow is a good one to fight the spider Splicers. You can also hack droids to fight for you, but the hacking mini game is a dredful, anoying mess so unless you use all of your adam upgradeing your hacking abilities.In the end i would definately recomend playing Bioshock as its a great, chilling experience with a cold (if a bit anti-climactic) story, but i would only buy if it was on offer as the game is diffinately without its flaws. Yet despite these flaws im looking farward to playing Bioshock Infinate (i tryed bioshock 2, but didnt enjoy it) to see a new story with some hopefuly improved gameplay.

Posted: January 13, 2013
												Deep at the bottom of the ocean is the city of Rapture. A city not for Gods or kings, A city for men.Built to be a utopia for mankind's greatest thinkers to prosper.The "world's best and brightest" were granted freedom of will and choice in Rapture, unrestrained by government, religion and similar established institutions. The results were amazing breakthroughs in robotics and genetics.But On December 31, 1958, a massive working-class uprising, led by a man known only as Atlas occurred in upper-class locations in the city, This sparked a civil war in Rapture and marked the beginning of the end.As the player you join the story after it has already concluded, left to wonder the ruins of this once great city, stalked by what's left of the survivors of the war, who due to genetic meddling are not quite human anymore.The game has totally immersive environments that the developers clearly enjoyed creating, accompanied by an original and genuinely interesting story that unfolds before you. With developers being far too willing to bypass story these days for the sake of throw away 'action' moments this game is an exception, Bioshock actually has strong literary references, with clear nods to books such as Logans run and George Orwell's 1984.A very impressive FPS not ruined by the trappings of most modern shooters, no unlimited regenerating health, no unlimited respawns or 10 minute cut scenes. This is an essential game for any self respecting FPS'er.The action starts early and never really slows down. Your own imagination decides how much you get from the conbat system and the enemy AI respodes well to your attack patterns and adjusts accordingly.Would you kindly go and pick up a copy of this game.

Posted: February 21, 2015
												What Bioschock lacks in gameplay fluidity as a first person shoother it makes up for with it's incredibly emmersive atmosphere. Though the incorporation of the plasmids is far from perfect and require you to switch not only between regular weapons but also between plasmids it's also fitting for the game because it makes you think more carefully about the attack combinations you are going to apply to each situation. If you make the mistake of equipping the wrong plasmid after discharging an entire cartridge on a big daddy he will make meatballs out of you.One thing that also works very well is the inclusion of RPG-like elements, such as different ammo types and power upgrades, that add another level of deapth to the game (pun intened) and require you to think more strategically and allow you to handle similar scenarios in different ways according to the upgrades you have.All this elements are combined perfectly with an intelligent and compelling story to create the experience that is Bioshock.

Posted: May 24, 2014
												Quite possibly my favourite game of all time.BioShock puts you in the shoes of a man named Jack, his plane crashing in the middle of the ocean.  With nowhere to go, he spots a lighthouse.  Going inside, he takes a Bathysphere into the underwater world of Rapture, a city where the brightest sparks of society have gathered.  Quite quickly you begin to notice that, while looking pretty on the outside, the city isn't what it seems to be; non-existent morals and a civil war have turned this city into an abandoned mess, its inhabitants becoming addicts and constantly searching for the wonder drug ADAM.  Having to defend yourself with weapons made by man and superpowers developed by the citizens (fueled by EVE) you'll have to protect yourself as everyone comes after you.  The rest of the plot is more enjoyable to experience yourself so I'll just stop here.This game is simply amazing.  The graphics still look great to me after SEVEN YEARS, Rapture itself still being nice to look at.  The atmosphere is fantastic and, for once, I actually gave a♥♥♥♥♥♥about the collectible items; the audio diaries you find are interesting and enjoyable to listen to, each one being a treat.  Combat is cool, the enemies are fun to fight, the characters are all extremely interesting, everything is a treat.  What the best feature was for me however was definitely the story of Rapture itself; a city gone mad, its leaders going crazy for power, a war tearing it apart, it's truly phenomenal.One can only ask how a game can be made as a spiritual successor yet still define itself in its own way.  Then you get BioShock and you understand.

Posted: July 7, 2015
												Yes I really enjoyed the game !!  It took me 51 hours or so that is what it says feels so much longer .First off I started playing games back in the day of 5.25 floppy drives , Internet what . and a 286 IBM was a top machine .I played a lot of board games mostly Military with my Dad growing up . as he got on in age I found the early games would be a okay substitute .  I wound up actually play testing some games for gary Grigsby . since i owned at the time the 2nd largest full line hobby store in VT specializing in Military models and history ..Okay about Bio shock I bought it on a sale here in the 3 pack . My roommates big shooter /role players say get the 3 pack so I did . Once I leaned the controls / got use to the first person shooting style once more , reminded me of old ,old Wolfenstien .  But with better graphics ,sound and such . Once settling into the game and new type of role playing . I found the game very enjoyable .  The  voice , animations are really nice . there is lots of blood when you kill not any nudity or sex type stuff in the game that i saw through my play through.  Okay I at times took breaks from the game went back to my military tatical games only to be drawn back to Bio shock , to find out what will happen next , where they are going to take me next to complete the task/ goal on hand . I got lost a lot but you hit the map/ hint key and you can figure out what you are doing . @ times I would need to actully take a step back from the game could that puzzle be that easy at this high a level in the game . This was a nice surprise saying that not everything is going always be harder as you go up in levels ,expect the unexpected .Okay look out for the ones that love sneaking up on you from the ceiling Ouch , took me a while to figure out why I was getting beat up before I saw them ...about the only thing that gave me a bad taste in my mouth with this game and this is not a spoiler but was the ending . Yes I spent all these hours , sleepless nights waiting for some major climex to the end game . thinking I would need be respaund several times at least maybe spend a hour trying to figure out the last level the finish to what was a great game full of intrigue  . conBut the end to me was a let down just expecting more then a few sentence type .   This is most likly just me and personal  since like i say I am a big player of Tactical/ strategic  war games . so lets say playing "Gettysburg Ultimate general "  all through out the 3 days of simulated battle time ity will build to a ending in good or bad results . Here the game just stopped  and was about it ..  But that is at this point the only issue i found to be negative so since I paid about 15 bucks for all 3 of the Bio shocks  have at least 50+ hrs in so far game 1 only am fairly new to the RPS systems /story type game plays .. I would sum the game up as a Buy Buy Buy  !!!!!!!  even if I do not play the next 2 in the serise  already have gotten more then my monies worth and have enjoyed many of days /nights playing the game . oh well this is only my 2-5 total ever review of a game I get no money or breaks for doing it just started today thinking I bought this game because of reviews  so I am going to review my games as I finish them or have say 20-30+ hours in them or learn the game playing parts so can give a good/bad review of the game . unlike some players right one since they get paid or free copy arangments How can you take a review to heart if the person has say 1.5 hrs of game play for a 60-70 hr game thanks for reading Bob CCrazyBearflutes .com

Posted: June 30, 2015
												========================Plot Twist Simulator 2007========================Atmosphere: Fantastic!Graphics: Considered that this is a game from 2007, the graphics are extremely good!Story: The story of the city is the best part about this game, I like the idea of having audio diaries spreaded around the city;(Spoiler!)I have no problem with the good ending, but the two other endings doesn't really make sense for me. The choices that I've made through out the game don't really correlate to those two ending scenes, there is no direct or logical relationship between harvesting little sisters and devouring the surface world. "But in the end even Rapture was not enough for you..." Seriously I just want to get the ♥♥♥♥ out of this underwater graveyard!Sound: Great in general, the ambient sounds are nicely done; but the dialogues from random splicers are a bit repetitive (Ive heard the "Jesus loves me yes I know" song for like seven times through out the game)Music: Fantastic! They have put a lot of effort into the soundtrack. I love Sander Cohen's masterpiece :DGameplay: The first half of the game is pretty fun, I enjoyed it very much. However during the mid-late game, things get a bit dull without new weapons and new plasmids but only upgrades. Good thing is, the story became more intense during this part of the game so that the game is still fun. The last part of the game gets interesting again because of the new mission type. The boss fight is a bit too easy,you just have to run around in circles, and then the fight is more or less the same as fighting 3 bouncers with bad range attacks, one after another.Overall: 8/10A wonderful game! One of my favourites!Although its gameplay is not as good as Bioshock 2, the mystery and atmosphere have made this game one of the best fps ever.Other notes: Easy mode is extremely easy, play on this setting only if you are new to video games; Medium mode is also easy, play on this setting if you are new to FPS games; Hard mode should be good for most players. On hard mode your health will drain very fast against stronger enemies, so you will have to explore the entire map for resources. Install Mods if you want a "true" hard mode.

Posted: July 25, 2015
												Bioshock is a brilliantly written with amazing gameplay, graphics and storyline. The true essence of Bioshock is captured by the beautiful and down right amazing storyline of the fallen Atlantis of a city, Rapture. The graphics are very good for something made in 2007 and very light weight on PC's everywhere. What I love the most is the games captivating take on Ayn Rand's Philosophy of objectivism and how that very philosophy would be the very fall of Rapture as it is.  WARNING: Some spoilers ahead   The Story of Rapture And the Events Leading Up to Bioshock 1 The game takes place in an underwater city known as Rapture, it was forged by the dreams of a wealthy Russian man by the name of Andrew Ryan. (or in Russian Originally posted by wiki: Андрей Раяновский  ) His Dream was to escape the clutching hands of political, religious, and social anxieties of a somewhat post WWII world. Rapture was built November 5th, 1946 and established in 1951. Ryan sought out to make a so called "perfect world" filled with men and women of free will and not men and women of the "parasites". Fast forward to December 31st, 1958 when the 1958 New Years Eve riots were started by no other then the man who was your so called friend in the game, Atlas. This caused major panic and many died in this act of terrorism. By 1960 the man who was posing as Atlas, Frank Fontaine was feeling the pressure of Ryan's pheromone-controlled army what what is called Splicers. In a last effort to turn things to his liking Fontaine called for the help of Andrew Ryan's illegitimate son Jack who was brainwashed in the the effects of a sleeper agent, someone who is activated by a simple word or phrase to complete a task preset by the activator. And we all know what that is "Would you Kindly". And then begins the events of Bioshock 1 where you play as Jack who is the sole survivor that suffers from a plane crash and has no other choice but to go into the creepy lighthouse the he ironically crashed in front of.   Pros:  Good Graphics (for 2007)Great soundtrack for the setting and feel of the gameLovin' the Big DaddiesGreat art deco designUnique enemies not just garden varieties Many great ways to improve your gameplay to how you like itGreat storyline, makes you feel like your actually in Rapture!Nice amounts of gore Cons: Sound and Audio problems for windows 8 users can be fixed with a guideYou may want to stock up on ammo near the end  Gameplay Overall the gameplay is amazing, I love the feel of the game and how complex and sophisticated the storyline is and how it ties in with the first, second, and third game even the DLC's tie in. I would compare this game to the mona lisa, it is a work of art and one of the best games i've ever played! My Take on the game  With no doubt in my mind I would give this game a 10 out of 10. It's captivating and surprising take on the philosophical idea of objectivism and how it might possibly affect a society much like Rapture its self. So Would you Kindly like this review and buy this game its worth the money! 												Loved this game. It may be a few years old, but I couldn't tell from the graphics, which were still stellar. The story is extremely well done and engaging throughout- you will be searching for every voxophone and going down every side corridor to learn more. Gameplay was also very fun- I played on Normal difficulty, which was challenging enough that I was never bored, while not being hard enough that I was frustrated. There weren't too many weapons to choose from (and to be honest some just didn't seem that effective compared to the standard Wrench) but I never found myself bored or distracted by that fact. Same with the Plasmids (basically, magic spells)- I almost always used the standard Electric Shock, but the others were still interesting and the gameplay forced you to use some of the other Plasmids in order to unlock secret areas or find hidden voxophones which advanced the story. In sum, I would give this game an 8/10, with a recommendation for people who want an engaging story to go with their gameplay.

Posted: July 23, 2015
												One of the best games ever I think, I can point out some negative things but they would feel quite forced, most notably low fov, even though there is a fix, and infuriating Little Sister sequence near the end.My awe for this game is almost like a fanboyism, as its gameplay in my opinion was unfairly criticized, since I find it genius, steadily growing more complex, and actually for the better. It sucked me in like a vortex and never let me go until the end. Gunplay felt fun, but it was only a small portion of an actual combat, the evergrowing arsenal of plasmids, perks and tools offered varied effects on enemies and security machines, with ability to hack nearly everything- I was able to create my own little strongholds, with its defences constantly clearing or weakening enemies that I could later scavenge. In the middle of battles with my hacked and friendly machines I was able to create tactics and strategies, adjusted to the kinds of enemies I face- electricity, fire, cold, launchpads and bees were all affecting them differently, combined with proper weapons I was able to figure out a position of advantage, and switch between tactics while keeping an eye on my resources. Resources are gained through scavenging corpses and containers as well as buying them from vending machines [also hackable], levels are vast and offer quite some room for exploration, with secrets scattered around the maps. Later in game there comes in a crafting system, as well as various junk that now can be used to craft, it's used at the special machines that offer an alternative to regular vending machines, as well as offer different kinds of ammunition, so that you are encouraged to use all of it, to gain most of the potential ammo. Later on we get chances to upgrade....well practically everything-perks, powers, unlocked slots for both, weapons, health and EVE capacity. Most of it is possible to gain in one playthrough if a player is stubborn, and instead of making him overpowered, it simply gives him more freedom of choice. People usually praise other elements of Bioshock, but for me gameplay is where it shines the brightest.This does not mean that they are wrong in terms of plot, it's amazing, full of crazy personas, enviromental storytelling, scattered recordings from the past of Rapture, and one of the most memorable plot twists in history of videogames. An Utopia at the bottom of the sea is marvelous, and amazes with its concept and story, I tried to look all around and through the windows, to see the whole of it and experience its beauty. I find it impossible that men from IG were crazy enough to develop such a game, the word ambitious doesn't even begin to cover it, they weren't crushed by the weight of this project and actually made something breathtaking and inspiring. Graphics were stunning and still look good, voice acting is brilliant, story is amazing, and gameplay is superb. I don't know how, but it's there- Bioshock; something that was meant to be a successor to System Shock, and I think there is no shame to actually call it that, while Bioshock is different from it- I might say it even reaches its level of brilliance.

Posted: September 17, 2015
												The spiritual successor to System Shock 2. Compared to System Shock 2 I think a lot of things got easier for player like we get the object arrow, no inventory management, easier resource management, no weapon degregation. Yet a lot of things changed for the better in a lot of ways. This game is super fun to play. You get to use all kinds of different strategies for defeating the enemies, be it setting up traps, turning them against each other, spells to stop them or just straight up blowing them up with different weapons. You also aren't really forced to stay on a path when it comes to that. You can constantly change the way you play on the fly, there's not really a leveling system that would need to be rerolled.I think the best thing about this game is in the atmosphere for sure. It feels like a real city. There's a lot variation too. Texture quality is good for the most part even for a game this old now. Not everything feels underwatery, but that is still the theme that repeats of course.What I really liked was the old school level design, like in Doom or something. There's a lot of secrets! If you just look to loot the enemies and some easy to spot safes you are missing a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of stuff! You really have to search for hidden doors, under the stairs, on the ceiling, on the bookshelfs. The devs really got good at hiding items from the player and trying to find everything was great.Sound design is excellent, you hear enemies talking behind corners all the time, saying really creepy♥♥♥♥♥♥ it's just awesome. Same with voice acting, excellent job by everyone. There's a LOT of audio recording in the world too so those who want to dig deeper about the issues in the city can do so. While those who just want to see gameplay and the major plot can skip all the recordings.Story and pacing is great. I hate super long cut scenes and long talks, not really the case here. There's not really many cut scenes. Everything is usually shown in the game world, a character appearing and talking to you or through the radio and I liked that approach a lot.If there's any negative about the game it's maybe the super simplified, black and white mechanics with little sisters. The game has 2 endings depending on your choice. The sort of grey area is missing, either you are a hero or you are not. I felt there should have been more choices throughout the game, like when you meet the citizens of the city- do you help them or destroy them? There could have been factions, side quests or something and multiple endings.Now the replayability is basicly on if you wanna see the other ending or not, which you probably should just youtube, since the game is so linear in that sense and you don't see anything new besides the 30sec ending video. Rather the replayability comes from the great gameplay, try different approach and difficulty setting, take more time to find the secrets, look at the level design, listen to the tapes.This game is easily 9/10 for me. If you end up liking this game a lot give System Shock 2 a try too, read the steam forums, update the textures and models a bit and it should still be a great game even today, That's what I did and liked it even more than Bioshock!

Posted: August 6, 2014
												Just finished Bioshock, and oh what a game. This game is superbly made in all aspects, including soundtrack, gameplay, graphics, story and overall fun, atmosphere and replay-ability. Firstly soundtrack, and it is simply sublime. I can and have listened to it while doing work or studying, it is that good. Not only is it awesome without the game, but when added to the game it increases the atmosphere ten-fold. Gameplay is fluid and very entertaining, with very awesome boss fights. Most people did not like the puzzle feature, but honestly I didn'd mind it. Yes, it did get very repititive, but it never took away from the experience overall. The graphics are fantastic, and the artsyle was fantastic and well backed up by the music which matches perfectly. Story is absolutely fantastic. It is interesting and complex, and contains messages and themes that make the game thought-provoking and insightful. Plasmids have a large variety and make the game a lot of fun. You can rarely shoot bees out of your hands to aid you in battle in many other games. As i spoke about before the atmosphere is created by the artstyle, story and soundtrack, which makes you feel amazing while playing. The game has multible endings and tonnes of content, which means I will defnitely return to rapture ASAP.Overall Bioshock is a fantastic game that is an easy 10/10 for me.

												Words cannot describe how amazing this game is.But I will try.Firstly, the story. The characters have amazing and well thought out backstories, the story of the game itself is compelling and will constantly twist, without it feeling overused. I don't often like to play a games campaign more than once, but this is definitely an exception. After completing the game once it gives you a completely different viewpoint the next playthrough.Next, the weapons. None are particularly overpowered, and everyone I know who plays has a different favourite gun. They all suit different playstyles in different ways incredibly effectively.Finally, the enemies. Loads of people think Big Daddies are invincible, or that the splicers would be too easy. Yet no, the game is perfectly balanced, Big Daddies can easily be beaten with a little thinking and Splicers are tweaked just enough to make them a slight challenge in large numbers.Overall, this game is probably my favourite of all time, just buy it. There isnt a 96 metascore for nothing! I also highly reccomend the other 2 aswell.

												None FPS fans read on!I am not, by any stretch of the imagination, a fan of FPS games. Instead I chose to creep around, hurling bees at the Splicers which was frankly as amusing the hundredth time to me as it was the first.The story is very good, boosted significantly by the environment, which makes you want more.  Having just finished the vastly inferior Bioshock Infinite I can in all honesty say that Bioshock is a one of a kind game; from stepping through those doors for the first time to the brief but satisfying (or not so much depending on your choices thoughout the game) ending, this is the kind of game that comes along once every so often and won't be repeated.Thumbs up, would shoot bees from hands again

Posted: July 3, 2014
												I've been taking the time to think about BioShock. On one hand, there is the "Cult of Shock 2" that retain a savage disdain for BioShock because of it's extremely obvious narrative and gameplay similarities to System Shock 2. On the other hand, there are gamers that reasonably acknowledge that BioShock's elements are derivitive of System Shock 2 and claim that the elements were streamlined for a newer generation. I know BioShock fans that have given copious amounts of evidence and suggestions to back this up, and I don't necessarily agree or disagree with that. That is a matter of prefrence. When someone takes the time to deconstruct and analyze System Shock 2, you'll find that it is a deeply and intracately woven role-playing experience where the player needed to become familliar with varying amounts of important elements to create their characters, specialize in specific statistics, and really just to experience the game once as an introduction to it all and play through a second time to experience the game properly. Many critics praised these very aspects that made System Shock 2 one of the greatest games ever created and the sales were miserable.When someone takes the time to deconstruct and analyze BioShock, you'll find a game that has that overall feeling of intracacy laced within the narrative with more understandable gameplay elements that were designed, in principle, to appeal to a large audience. There are elements that can be considered RPG elements and the game had the basis of it's core gameplay display itself as a suspense game in a few areas and a balls-to-the-wall action FPS in most others. The gaming community—especially the parts of it that sided with the "Cult of Shock 2"—was split and BioShock became 2K Games' most profitable franchise at that time.When you take a look at the bigger picture, System Shock 2 and BioShock are two completely different games in principle and two very similar games in execution. When you get down to it, the "dumbing down" of System Shock 2's qualities was enforced, not by a corporate publisher or a greedy fat man in a black suit, but by the developers' own desire to make their baby, System Shock 2, more understandable. If you take the time to search up some interviews and stuff for System Shock 2 featuring Ken Levine and Looking Glass Studios (which is now 2K Games), you can tell that System Shock 2 was their pride and joy, and it must have been devastating when it became ignored by the central PC community. To that extent, I can understand more reasonably (and even forgive) a few of my previous issues with this title. I used to have a psychotic hatred for this game based on System Shock 2, and my previous review that I wrote for this game was an over-glorified comparison to System Shock 2. I'm not going to make the same mistake here in this rewrite, as I've come to the conclusion that to judge BioShock by System Shock 2 would be very unfair, as I think any fan of System Shock 2 would probably agree when I say that System Shock 2 is the better of the two titles.BioShock, on its own, is an okay game. I don't think it's the genre-defining work of art that the gaming industry seems to think it is, but I don't think that it's the water-logged, hollowed out corpse of SS2 that the "Cult of Shock 2" thinks it is. It does a few things right and it does a lot of things wrong, and in the very end it's up to the fans of System Shock 2 to decide whether or not they want to take BioShock as its own experience. As one of the BIGGEST fans of SS2 out there, I'm reviewing this game from that perspective.The gameplay elements found in BioShock all consist of unorthodox forms of first-person shooting and RPG elements without numbers. This game borrows implicitly from SS2's horror elements by including a few scenes that really do peak the player's intrest, but the attempts at horror are completely futile. The game can't be called a survival game because it isn't one, and resource management is way too easy, even on difficulty settings over Normal. These sections are far and few between as most of the game plays as a balls-to-the-wall action shooter. However, these sections are mediated by fluent pace changes every so often. Whereas other games from 2007 would often have you just shooting at everything coming by, this game takes a slower, more methodical approach to let you appreciate the vibe of what you're doing and really take in the enviorment as well as the NPCs populating it. The NPCs are hopeless drug addicts; you're a killer, and you feel like one...except when you deal with Big Daddies and Little Sisters.Despite everything else wrong with the game, *BIG DADDIES ARE FRIGGING AWESOME*, and anyone who tells you otherwise hasn't played this game. The Little Sisters, on the other hand, are the *lowest* rung on the morality ladder. Essentailly, the Little Sisters are little girls that you can either choose to save or harvest for Adam. You get more Adam for harvesting them and less for saving them. If you save all of them, you get the good ending, and if you harvest just ONE of them, you get the bad ending. Without spoiling anything, they both mean absolutely nothing and you can just watch them on YouTube. Without any character development, killing or saving the Little Girls becomes based on the reward. Would you rather have less Adam or more Adam? Exactly.The gunplay is very unsatisfying. I'm going to be a hypocrite for a few characters and say that SS2 also had unsatisfying gunplay, but you almost never used your gun because ammo was low and most of the gunplay was backed up by the horror elements of the game. Here, the weak sounding weapons and overexaggerated reactions result in gunplay that feels like a chore to sort through. There are moments when it's satisfying to take down a Big Daddy, but that's satisfaction from the challenge and not the actual gunplay.Besides shooting, BioShock includes two performance enhancing bodily modifications called "Plasmids" and "Gene Tonics". Plasmids are essentially powers you recieve from completing missions (and you can always buy them at the vending machine). Gene Tonics are the RPG Elements without numbers I was writing about earlier. They are pretty much character enhancements that set up your character to adopt certain play styles. For example, you can put together an invisibility tonic and a melee damage tonic to take on the role of a stealth assassin. For the game's other shortcomings, that's pretty cool.The game also features hacking mini-games in the form of circuit-based puzzles. You connect a set of pipes so water can successfully travel from one end of the circuit to another. While doing this, the game pauses and you always will have the right pieces at the right time, killing tension. If they really wanted to include some much needed tension, then they could have accelerated the current of the water whenever a piece was misplaced, or they could have provided a certain amount of each directional pipe, causing some inevitable ambiguation as to where to construct a direct path. They also could have made it so there was a tangible loss with each failure. There is no tangible loss when dying. There are Vita Chambers, which are essentially respawn points that make the game much easier than it already is, and then there's just going back to the main menu if you decide to shut it off.Like I said, I don't hate BioShock, nor do I carry the attitude I once had towards it like the "Cult of Shock 2". I don't think it's a revolutionary work of art either. I think it's okay. Not terrible, but not great. It's great in some areas and abhorrent in others, and what's there good is great and what's bad is horrible.3/5 - Okay. Worth a rental or a purchase (only if the price goes down).

												As a game alone, could I recommend Bioshock?  The gunplay is floaty and 'off'.  It's difficult to explain, but the guns in Bioshock don't give as much feedback and aren't as satisfying as guns in games today.  Even comparing it to other games around the time of its release in 2007 doesn't do it much good.  Okay, so boo hoo, the "Run 'n' Gun" strategy isn't going to work in this game.  However, another mechanic balances this out - the use of plasmids.  These genetically granted powers allow you to stun, burn, and freeze enemies, allowing for a wide variety of strategies and traps. Zapping an enemy with lightning sure does make it a lot easier to get close enough to force-feed him a belt of ammo.Exploration is very rewarding in this game.  So much so, that if you're like me, you'll end up being full of loot half the time.  While I thought that they could scale back on how much loot was lying around the ravenged city of Rapture, I really liked the map you're given.  It highlighted areas you had already explored, which meant you wouldn't spend ten minutes backtracking trying to find that one door you *thought* was where you were supposed to go, so you skipped it to keep looking for loot, but it turns out you actually went the right way and so now you need to find it again to explore the hallway and two rooms behind it.I also really liked how fights with the Big Daddies worked.  They weren't agressive unless you attacked them, meaning you could hold off killing them until you were prepared; however, even when fully prepared, Big Daddies have a couple different attacks, making them formidable opponents.Based on gameplay alone, Bioshock is fun, but it hasn't exactly aged gracefully.  Don't interpret that to mean I don't like the game though.  Both the story and characters are very engaging.  It's the small things, like the interactions between the Big Daddies and their Little Sisters and "idle dialouge" (randomly chosen lines spoken by enemies that have little to no bearing on the story/plot and only serve to heighten atmosphere), that really made me enjoy this game.Having just competed the entire game a second time, I plan on going back for at least a third.

												The Good:+amazing atmosphere+still decent graphics+many ways to customize your character+intriguing story+a lot of morbid humor+awesome characters (though sadly you'll only ever directly meet a handful of them)+rewards you for exploring the world+pretty challengingThe Bad:-game feels little bit too long (if you took your time to explore everything)-physics are calculated at low fps (minor complaint)-sometimes you get into ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t situations and just die if you don't play on easy (4 splicers + big daddy + a rocket turret + a bunch of drones)-weapons with normal ammo feel pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ after a while, even upgraded-Adam is not even that important while health + Eve packs/money are very important (the game often tries to tell you how important Adam is) -the game crashes a lot for some people This is a great game, though it feels like it could've been 10-20% shorter. Some missions felt like they added filler material to make the game longer. For example instead of picking up 5 pieces of one item, I had to pick up 5 pieces of 3 items. Or kill different people spread across the entire map etc. The atmosphere in this game is really great and it sort of reminds me of Half Life, Portal 2 and Metro 2033 combined. The graphics are a bit outdated but still look pretty good and performance was great for me as well. The weapon system is fairly good. You can choose between quite a few weapons, and the ammo you wanna use. You can also upgrade those weapons at weapon upgrade stations which you'll find sometimes. Also, you can use Plasmids, which are sort of like spells, such as igniting enemies, shocking enemies, enraging enemies (making them attack other enemies) etc. These plasmids come in various forms, and can also be upgraded. You can use them to defeat enemies, but you can also use them to help you open doors, melt ice that blocks your path etc. Another aspect worth mentioning is that you can collect passive abilities which you can use to customize your character depending on your playstyle. In this regard, Bioshock is very much an RPG.

BioShock™ as well as the Bioshock series will always remain as one of the best FPS game. It will surely bring you an awesome experience (and touching as well...). The AI are well designed, they are not some random guys just standing there waiting to be killed. To be honest, sometimes the Splicers, specially Big Daddies really annoyed me because it took me a while in order to defeat just only one guy (but still, i think that's what made BioShock even better). When i see the graphics in game, i couldn't belive this game was released in 2007. The landscape in Rapture is so realistic, the lights, the water, the smoke, the blood, all contributed to the "Fallen Rapture" scenery perfectly. The gameplay is great too, at first when i was entering Rapture as Jack, i knew i had to play "sneaky-beaky like." But as i advanced throughout the game, i realized that i can both stealth and play "Rambo" at the sametime. And believe me, it feels really awesome when you've killed a Leadhead Splicer (LoL). The sound also made big contributions to the game as well, this is the first game that allows me to hear the enemies singing, muttering, or just talking about weird-random things, it made me feel creepy and funny at the same time.I don think that this game has any cons, it's just too perfect, and here are my ratings:Storyline: 10/10Graphics: 9.5/10Gameplay: 9/10Sound: 9.5/10"And now, would you kindly buy and play this game without hesitation?"

												This is honestly one of my favorite games of all time, due to it's incredible story, atmosphere, and social commentary. The graphics are still stunning for this day and age, but you shouldn't even think of playing this game for graphics. Do that with Bioshock Infinite. This game, though, is raw and horrific. It is relentless and will have you questioning your morals while playing it. While not open world, Bioshock has an incredibly captivating setting of Rapture, an underwater city ravaged by political corruptness. The special "abilities" of freezing, electrocuting, and tormenting people feels sadistically satisfying, and gunplay is comfortable for even the most experienced FPS players. The atmosphere never lets up, and you will come across things you can't believe - characters with sickening goals and disturbing monologues. One early game, a doctor, is incredibly terrifying. But, enough rambling - I can't stress enough that you need to sit down with this game and appreciate what a gem it is in the gaming industry.

 Originally posted on May 25, 2009 Bioshock is an experience that will not leave me for years to come. From the very first few moments of the plane crash, to the first time you encounter a big daddy, to the confrontation with Ryan, and the completion of Cohen's masterpiece, Bioshock is simply amazing.First, visually it is stunning, even two years on. The art design, more than the technical graphics is absolutely astounding. That and the water looks incredibly real, and the feeling that everything is leaking is wonderfully atmospheric. The way the plasmids destroy your hand is fascinating, and seeing the decay in a once mighty utopia is something that words could never fully describe.The audio also greatly contributes to the game, with the audio diaries standing out in particular. Listening to them in order gives the player a wonderful and frightening picture of how Rapture tore itself apart. The side stories that the audio diaries give you a glimpse into create memorable and emotionally interesting characters that the player never actually meets. In fact, some of the most memorable characters in the game are already long dead by the time the player arrives. It is the reconstruction of their actions that is so fascinating.The Music, both composed for Bioshock (the score) and the period music that plays throughout Rapture is incredible. The pieces that you hear on jukeboxes and radios are classics that add to the atmosphere of Rapture as a time capsule greatly.The gameplay, from a shooter perspective is fun and varied, with many different types of enemies, and a good variety of weapons with upgrades and different types of ammo for each. In addition, you have plasmids and gene tonics, and various upgrades for them which really enhance the gameplay level. You can invent new ammo and tonics, buy supplies, and hack about any machine in the game, including turrets and bots to help you. There are so many ways to play that game that it can even be a little overwhelming at times, and it does tend to make the game a little too easy.Even so, Bioshock is an incredible experience, and even just for the story and exploring the environment, it is a must buy, and one of the most memorable games I've played in a while.

												The "FPSRPG" kind of games (or as i like to call them, "deus ex" kind of games) can be counted on the fingers of a hand, solely because of the effort that must be put on these kind of titles and the variety that must be offered, but once they are created, and well, they become eternal masterpieces. Bioshock is one of them.The story is finely narrated without pinching the player through boring cutscenes or text walls, but simply by using the "3d actors" that the game offers or the audio logs gathered in an unique 50's nostalgic world filled of details and icons that got bethesda so much in love that they copied that while making Fallout 3 (see pip-boy and the plasmid tutorials).The plot is in background but at the same time will make the player wanting to know more, as you make way through halls of debrises and destruction with your wrench.The gameplay, as in every "Deus ex-y" game, is satisfying and rewarding, made out of many skills and little things to do that can make the player replay the game many more times to see how the character can change in every gameplay. It's good to pick up new skills, it feels good to shoot with your weapons or to thunderstrike with your hands, but if i compare this to his father (System shock 2), the game feels, sure, more dynamic, but ridicolously easy and criminally short.Gameplay: 9/10Story: 8/10Soundtrack 8.5/10Replayability 8.5/10The "must play" for every player that likes RPG-FPS kind of game, and the starting point to whoever wants to begin a genre like that, it's a pity that there aren't as many games as bioshock 1.

It seemed like it would be the perfect game for me...The storyline, i must say is truly wonderful, an innovative idea that's extremely well thought out and executed. This is accompanied by the also stunning visuals and environment style which are perfect for achieving the grungy, dystopian and eerie style that’s so synonymous with the series.Unfortunately, this did not make me impressed enough with the game enough to actually fall in love with it, or even like it slightly more than the average RPG. Which brings me on to my next point… It’s so damn repetitive. With the occasional plot point being the only thing that’s keeping you going, you battle through hordes of splicers again and again… and again…Basically, the longer you play, the more bored you get. With one or two twists in the story line that re-activate your interest in the game occasionally, I can say… I was vey disappointed in the game.It’s a beautifully made, artistic… boring game. Not saying it's bad, but its just quite boring at times. 60/100BTW This is a good game, but during the middle of it? It's pretty damn boring.

Posted: January 13, 2013
												Deep at the bottom of the ocean is the city of Rapture. A city not for Gods or kings, A city for men.Built to be a utopia for mankind's greatest thinkers to prosper.The "world's best and brightest" were granted freedom of will and choice in Rapture, unrestrained by government, religion and similar established institutions. The results were amazing breakthroughs in robotics and genetics.But On December 31, 1958, a massive working-class uprising, led by a man known only as Atlas occurred in upper-class locations in the city, This sparked a civil war in Rapture and marked the beginning of the end.As the player you join the story after it has already concluded, left to wonder the ruins of this once great city, stalked by what's left of the survivors of the war, who due to genetic meddling are not quite human anymore.The game has totally immersive environments that the developers clearly enjoyed creating, accompanied by an original and genuinely interesting story that unfolds before you. With developers being far too willing to bypass story these days for the sake of throw away 'action' moments this game is an exception, Bioshock actually has strong literary references, with clear nods to books such as Logans run and George Orwell's 1984.A very impressive FPS not ruined by the trappings of most modern shooters, no unlimited regenerating health, no unlimited respawns or 10 minute cut scenes. This is an essential game for any self respecting FPS'er.The action starts early and never really slows down. Your own imagination decides how much you get from the conbat system and the enemy AI respodes well to your attack patterns and adjusts accordingly.Would you kindly go and pick up a copy of this game.

Posted: July 9, 2016
BioShock™ as well as the Bioshock series will always remain as one of the best FPS game. The storyline is very thought-provoking with breathtaking twist and turns, together with many riddles throughout the game, from collecting and listening to diaries, to solving puzzels in order to advance through the game. It will surely bring you an awesome experience (and touching as well...). The AI are well designed, they are not some random guys just standing there waiting to be killed. To be honest, sometimes the Splicers, specially Big Daddies really annoyed me because it took me a while in order to defeat just only one guy (but still, i think that's what made BioShock even better). When i see the graphics in game, i couldn't belive this game was released in 2007. The landscape in Rapture is so realistic, the lights, the water, the smoke, the blood, all contributed to the "Fallen Rapture" scenery perfectly. The gameplay is great too, at first when i was entering Rapture as Jack, i knew i had to play "sneaky-beaky like." But as i advanced throughout the game, i realized that i can both stealth and play "Rambo" at the sametime. And believe me, it feels really awesome when you've killed a Leadhead Splicer (LoL). The sound also made big contributions to the game as well, this is the first game that allows me to hear the enemies singing, muttering, or just talking about weird-random things, it made me feel creepy and funny at the same time.I don think that this game has any cons, it's just too perfect, and here are my ratings:Storyline: 10/10Graphics: 9.5/10Gameplay: 9/10Sound: 9.5/10"And now, would you kindly buy and play this game without hesitation?"

												This game is my favorite game ever and the fps game I played. You play as Jack as you discover the secrets of Rapture, Andrew Ryan, and Atlas. You will have to face splicers and big daddies to win. The atmosphere is amazing and the sense of claustrophobia is always there. The scariest part is before the final boss. It covers themes like addiction, capitalism, ones own free will, and even at the end family. The combat is the best. You have 9 weapons and they all used to great effectiveness, the only one that I didn't like was chemical thrower which at most times was useless especially against Big Daddies minus the shock gel which destroys the bouncer and is good against the Rosie. You also have the use of plasmids which lets shoot lightning, freeze enemies, and shoot BEES!!!! They each have there own influence on different enemies and environment. You go from area to area, which are all unique and have there own special themes, my personal favorites were Hephaestus and Fort Frolic. This game is so good and it deservers a 100/100. Would you kindly give this game a try?
